What accounts or\nledgers would this auditor want to review, and by what criteria would he\njudge their adequacy? In reading this book I could not help thinking of Mark\nAnielski as \u201cGod\u2019s auditor.\u201d I do not want to attribute to Mark any divine au-\nthority or ability (he certainly does not claim such), nor am I sure that the\nAlmighty would not ask for some parts of the report to be redone. Of course\nan omniscient God has no need of an auditor\u2019s report, and the intended audi-\nence and bene\u0160ciary of the audit is us human beings.\n\nThe main criterion guiding the audit is \u201cgenuine well-being\u201d which is\nderived from \u201cgenuine wealth,\u201d which in turn consists of \u0160ve capital accounts\nthat assess both the quantity and quality of each type of capital. These \u0160ve\ncapitals are: (1) human capital \u2014 individual minds, bodies, spirits and their\ncapabilities; (2) social capital \u2014 quality and strength of our relations in com-\nmunity: trust, honesty, common values, including tolerance; (3) natural capi-\ntal \u2014stocks and funds of things in nature that yield \u0161ows of natural resources\nand life-supporting ecosystem services; (4) built capital \u2014machines, tools,\ndurable consumer goods; (5) \u0160nancial capital \u2014 money and other liquid as-\nsets, fungible and acceptable for payment of transactions and debts.\n\nOur current system of national accounts focuses on (5), pays some atten-\ntion to (4), and ignores (1), (2), and (3). The problem is that it is the \u0160rst three\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page xv\n\n\n\nthat are most responsible for genuine well-being. While there is some mar-\nginal substitution possible among these different forms of capital (often\noveremphasized by economists who advise not to worry about depleting, say,\nnatural capital as long as you accumulate an \u201cequal amount\u201d of built capital\nor human capital), it is important to recognize, as Anielski does, that the dif-\nferent forms of capital are mainly complementary. A shortage of any one lim-\nits the productivity of the others. In particular \u0160nancial capital quickly be-\ncomes worthless as natural capital is excessively depleted. And a lack of trust\n(social capital) limits the value of knowledge (human capital), etc. The fact\nthat \u0160nancial capital is the most measurable category has biased our attention\ntoo much in its direction. But just how measurable is money really? Do we\nmean M1, M2, or M3, and what kind of measuring rod is it that can be created\nout of nothing and then destroyed, and while it exists can become longer or\nshorter? We must not make a fetish out of measurability. What really counts\nis often not countable. Assets can be recognized and celebrated and main-\ntained and cared for even if we cannot add and subtract them.\n\nAnielski learns from many people: from Luca Pacioli the Italian inventor\nof double-entry bookkeeping, from Karl-Henrik Robert of the Natural Step,\nand Mathis Wackernagel of the Ecological Footprint analysis, and from many\nothers, including even me, which makes this old professor feel good. He looks\nat examples ranging from Ray Anderson\u2019s Interface Carpet Co. with its eco-\nlogical closed loop materials accounting, to China and the idea of xiaokang, or\nthe\u201cmoderatelywelloff society\u201dasanalternativetotheever-growing economy.\nHe studies the Italian province of Emilia Romagna, the Inuit, Bhutan, and\nthe city of Santa Monica. The style ranges from textbook to personal memoir,\nto philosophical re\u0161ection, but all aimed at elucidating and applying the con-\ncept of Genuine Wealth.\n\nSo, gentle reader, I will take up no more of your time with further sum-\nmary and endorsement. After all, you now have the book in your hands, so by\nall means read it carefully. You will be glad you did.\n\n\u2014 Herman E. Daly\n\nHerman E. Daly is currently Professor at the University of Maryland, School of Public Affairs,\nand has previously served as Senior Economist in the Environment Department of the World Bank.\nHe is the author of over a hundred articles in professional journals and anthologies, as well as\nnumerous books, including Beyond Growth and, with John B. Cobb, Jr., For the Common\nGood. He has received Sweden\u2019s Honorary Right Livelihood Award, and the Heineken Prize for\nEnvironmental Science awarded by the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences.\n\nxvi The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page xvi\n\n\n\nxvii\n\nIntroduction\n\nIBELIEVE WE ALL SHARE a common yearning for happiness and ultimately\nlove. Each of us has our own unique journey in discovering these ultimate\n\nends. But what are the determinants of happiness and our conditions of well-\nbeing \u2014 our genuine wealth? What, as Robert Kennedy challenged, makes\nlife worthwhile? How might we measure our happiness and incorporate these\nmeasures into conventional economic measures of progress like the GDP? \n\nPrompted by such nagging questions I began a journey into the origins\nof economic thought and economic systems. I realized that economics is more\nlike a religion than either art or science. The more I probed its tenets, the\nmore the scales of economic dogma fell from my own eyes and the eyes of\nthose with whom I shared my ideas. In a sense our hearts began to open to\ntruths that have long been sti\u0161ed.\n\nWhile some have de\u0160ned economics as the dismal science, I \u0160nd it akin\nto religion precisely because economic principles and tools form the guidance\nsystem of our modern states. Economists are the high priests of our capitalist\nsystems. I count myself among the economic priesthood \u2014 but I am a priest\nwho longs to understand the very premises and value-origins of our thought.\nAs a professor of business and economics, I have found a hunger among my\nstudents to understand more clearly the articles of faith behind business prac-\ntices. Many students question whether pro\u0160t and \u0160nancial wealth maximiza-\ntion should be the primary goals of business; they long for a more meaningful\nworld where corporations are governed by ethics and principles of social and\nenvironmental responsibility. I am buoyed by this new generation of business\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page xvii\n\n\n\nand economic graduates who understand at the heart level that the current\n\u201cnew world order\u201d can and must change.\n\nIn economics we have reduced humanity to a collection of individual, in-\ndependent, utility maximizing creatures. Success is de\u0160ned by the accumula-\ntion of material and \u0160nancial wealth over a lifetime. We are born into this free\nmarket ideology without questioning its morality or ethical foundations. So\nwatermarked is this spirit of economics and capitalism on our lives that even\nthough our hearts cry out for a more meaningful and genuine existence, we\nare sucked back into the squirrel cage of capitalism, running faster and faster\nto \u201ckeep up with the Jones,\u201d lamenting as we imagine a simpler, more mean-\ningful, more genuine life. \n\nI \u0160rmly believe we are at an important tipping point in human history. A\nshared consciousness is emerging which will be supported by enlightened,\nlife-af\u0160rming economics. This book presents my future vision: stewardship of\nwhat I call Genuine Wealth \u2014 those conditions of well-being that align with\nour heartfelt values about what makes life worth living. \n\nThe Economics of Happiness has four primary goals.First, I explore the nature\nand spirit of the current economic system. I want to better understand why\nmany in the sustainability movement can\u2019t seem to move towards a genuine,\nliving and sustainable economic system. I wonder how Adam Smith\u2019s seminal\neconomics text,TheWealth of Nations, failed toconsider theOldEnglishorigins\nof theword\u201cwealth,\u201dwhichliterallymeans\u201ctheconditionsofwell-being.\u201d The\nimportant work of Amitore Fanfani traced economic and capitalistic think-\ning back to the European Middle Ages where Fanfani located a pre-capitalist\nmodel that the sustainability movement may \u0160nd desirable.\n\nMy second goal is to introduce the concept of Genuine Wealth: a new\nand compelling model for managing our personal, household, business and\ncommunity well-being in accordance with the values that de\u0160ne our quality\nof life. Genuine Wealth is a practical system which measures and manages for\nsustainability the total capital assets of a community or organization. Syn-\nthesizing emerging concepts like natural capital and social capital, Genuine\nWealth creates a more comprehensive accounting system where human, so-\ncial, natural, built and \u0160nancial capital are all integrated into the balance sheet.\nThis vision of a living, sustainable economy is founded on the mutually rein-\nforcing and integrated principles of ef\u0160ciency, equity and reciprocity and was\ninspired by the cooperative economy of Emilia Romagna, a \u0161ourishing and\nvibrant region of Italy.\n\nxviii The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page xviii\n\n\n\nThirdly I provide examples of applications of the Genuine Wealth model\nat the personal/household, corporate/business, community, state/provincial\nand national scales. I present stories from Nunavut in Canada\u2019s Arctic, the City\nof Santa Monica, California and Leduc, Alberta and explore systems like the US\nGenuine Progress Indicators (GPI) and the Alberta GPI Sustainable Well-\nbeing Accounting System.\n\nFourthly I examine the nature of money and the current debt-based\nbanking system. Mountains of unsustainable debt and the practice of charg-\ning interest on loans actually lead to the destruction of living capital and\nfundamentally undermine sustainable economies of well-being and happi-\nness. I offer examples of alternatives to the current banking systems like the\nJAK Members Bank in Sweden, a cooperative member-owned bank that does\nnot charge interest on loans. I present a Genuine Wealth money and banking\nmodel that returns the power of money creation to the people in community.\nMoney could be created to serve the genuine needs of an economy of happi-\nness, and private banks, by providing wise \u0160nancial counsel to households\nand businesses, could contribute directly to the development of genuine\neconomies of well-being.\n\nWhile there is a growing library of books about sustainability, I offer\nhere a new paradigm which is also a pragmatic system for the management\nand stewardship of the common wealth of nations. While other books might\ndespair at the sad state of the world and our environment, The Economics of\nHappiness holds out hope that a genuine renaissance in economics, accounting\nand business practices is possible and that you and I can build communities of\ngenuine well-being and happiness, a vision that is shared by many. This book\nis optimistic and predicated on faith that people of all nations understand in-\ntuitively what needs to change in order for humanity to move towards a more\nsustainable future.\n\n\u2014 Mark Anielski\n\nEdmonton, Alberta, Canada\n\nIntroduction xix\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page xix\n\n\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page xx\n\n\n\n1\n\nChapter 1\n\nMy Journey to Genuine Wealth\n\nMany people have asked me \u201chow did you get to where you are?\u201d\nMy professional background includes economics, forestry, accounting\n\nand religious studies. After three university degrees and years working as a\nprofessional economist, I have developed an overview of the ways economic\nsystems operate throughout the world. In my inquiry into economic systems\nI continue to ask the simple question \u201cwhy?\u201d\n\n\u2022 Why do economists, \u0160nancial analysts, politicians and media \u0160xate on\ngrowth measures (such as the GDP or gross domestic product) as the key\nindicator of human progress? \n\n\u2022 Why do economy and stock market indices have to keep growing if a com-\nmunity has achieved levels of material self-suf\u0160ciency and quality of life?\n\n\u2022 What is money and where does it come from? \n\u2022 Why is money always scarce? \n\u2022 What\u2019s wrong with a steady-state, subsistence economy which has\n\nachieved suf\u0160ciency and homeostasis? \n\u2022 Why does free-market, capitalist economics look more like a cancer cell\n\nthan the self-renewing life cycle of an ancient forest? \n\u2022 What is driving our more-growth, more-consumption obsession? \n\u2022 Why aren\u2019t economists and our leaders asking hard questions: more\n\ngrowth of what? for whom? \n\nThese are just some of the questions I began to ask myself as an economist\nworking in the Canadian province of Alberta. As a senior government\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 1\n\n\n\neconomic policy analyst at Alberta Environment my primary task was to de-\nrive monetary value for Alberta\u2019s natural capital assets or natural resources;\nmany of them, like wilderness, had no price in a market. I was puzzled that\nwe had to reduce the value of everything to a monetary \u0160gure so it could\ncount. If something had no monetary value \u2014 like the joy of a wilderness ex-\nperience or the sight of a grizzly bear \u2014 did this mean that it was worthless?\nI began questioning the meaning of the word value. I was learning that there\nmight be market and non-market values. Economist and author Marilyn\nWaring offered my \u0160rst plain language lesson in the art of national income ac-\ncounting and the shortcomings of the gross domestic product (GDP) as a\nmeasure of progress.1 Marilyn noted that if you want fantastic GDP growth\nyou would deliberately crash an oil tanker like the Exxon Valdez into an\nAlaskan reef rather than deliver its cargo of oil safely to a Seattle port. Mari-\nlyn was the \u0160rst economist to point out to me the origins of the word value\n(from the Latin valere meaning \u201cshowing worth\u201d). Her warnings about the\nshortcoming of the GNP (the gross national product, the GDP\u2019s cousin) as a\nmeasure of progress had been voiced by Robert Kennedy in 1968 just a few\nweeks before his untimely assassination. Kennedy lamented that while the\nGNP might be great at adding up all the money we spend on goods and serv-\nices in an economy, it was a lousy measure of what mattered most to Ameri-\ncans: their quality of life. No other politician has given such a poignant cri-\ntique of the world\u2019s key measure of progress.2 For me, Kennedy\u2019s rebuke was\na clarion call to research and develop better systems of measuring human\nprogress and well-being that make common sense to average citizens and\nalign with their values.\n\nLearning about natural capital and sustainability\nWith these insights, I began to examine new models for measuring progress,\nsustainability and well-being. I began to explore new methods for accounting\nor measuring sustainability, \u0160rst focused on natural capital and then expand-\ning into other forms of capital accounting including human capital (like\ntime, knowledge and health) and social capital3 (like trust and the strength of\nrelationships). In 1991 I discovered the pioneering work of Robert Repetto at\nthe World Resources Institute in Washington. Repetto argued that account-\nants should treat nature\u2019s capital in the same way they treat manufactured or\nproduced capital like buildings, equipment and computers. Accounting\nshould acknowledge that nature\u2019s capital \u2014 like forests, oil and agricultural\n\n2 The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 2\n\n\n\nsoils \u2014 can either depreciate (that is, be depleted or degraded) or appreciate\n(that is, grow in volume or quality). Repetto\u2019s primary argument made good\nsense. I began to ask \u201cwhy don\u2019t we keep a balance sheet for nature\u2019s capital\nassets like forests, oil, gas, coal, wildlife, water and soils that are so vital to\nAlberta\u2019s and Canada\u2019s economy?\u201d I reasoned that economists ignored the\nvalue of nature\u2019s capital either because it was too hard to measure or count or\nbecause it was politically expedient.\n\nWith my curiosity piqued, I began informally examining Alberta\u2019s nat-\nural assets beginning with forests, oil/natural gas and carbon. Were Alberta\u2019s\nforests being managed sustainably? How many years of oil and natural gas\nsupply did Alberta have left? My preliminary results suggested that Alberta\u2019s\nforests might be approaching an unsustainability threshold: more trees were\nbeing harvested and destroyed by \u0160re and insects than the reported annual\ngrowth of the total forest. More disconcertingly, I lacked con\u0160dence in the an-\nnual growth rate of the forest. That was akin to lacking con\u0160dence in the rev-\nenue line on a conventional income statement or the interest rate on my bank\naccount! When I looked at oil and gas natural capital accounts, I was shocked\nto discover that the reserve life or years of future production of conventional\noil and natural gas left, at current production rates, was shrinking rapidly.\nBy my calculations Alberta would exhaust its precious oil and gas reserves\nwithin 12 years without new discoveries. Without information which natural\ncapital accounting provides to guide economic policy decisions, how could\nAlberta decision makers insure the long-term sustainability of Alberta\u2019s nat-\nural capital assets? How could there be so little interest shown in natural cap-\nital accounting practices by a government committed to accountability and\nperformance measurement? \n\nIn constructing these early natural capital accounts I learned an impor-\ntant lesson. While we had mountains of data and information, we seemed to\nlack the wisdom or capacity to understand what all the information was\ntelling us about sustainability. We had lost sight of the forest, so focused were\nwe on making money on the harvesting and export of trees. I realized that\nthere was an important role for accountants and economists to play in devel-\noping new capital accounting tools to assess the long-term sustainability of\nnature\u2019s capital assets as well as human and social capital. Economists could\nbegin developing revised national income accounts and adjusted GDP \u0160gures\nthat counted natural, human and social capital depreciation. I knew that such\naccounts could be constructed from the data we currently collected on the\n\nMy Journey to Genuine Wealth 3\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 3\n\n\n\nphysical state of our forests and other natural capital. Yet I knew that, like all\nmajor changes, a move to incorporate natural capital into the balance sheet of\nthe nation would be faced with resistance and reluctance to change. Fortu-\nnately almost 15 years later, the term natural capital has been popularized by\nothers (including by the Canada West Foundation in Calgary). Yet even today\nneither Canada\u2019s nor Alberta\u2019s income accounts or GDP \u0160gures count natural\ncapital assets that are critical to the well-being of Canadians. \n\nSince the early 1990s the idea of natural capitalism \u2014 that nature\u2019s as-\nsets or capital form one of the key foundations of an economy \u2014 has gained\npopularity in many books, countless articles and conferences. Natural Capi-\ntalism by Paul Hawken, Amory Lovins and Hunter Lovins contributed to this\ndebate. Its authors suggested that the world is on the verge of a new industri-\nal revolution founded on the principles of a system called natural capitalism.\nThey argued that traditional capitalism has always neglected to assign mone-\ntary value to its largest stock of capital \u2014 namely, the natural resources and\necosystem services that make possible all economic activity and all life. Nat-\nural capitalism, they stated, takes a proper and full accounting of these costs\nand redesigns industry on biological models that result in zero waste, shifts\nthe economy from the episodic acquisition of goods to the continual \u0161ow of\nvalue and service and prudently invests in sustaining and expanding stores of\nnatural capital. These words were music to my ears.4\n\nEncouraged by pioneering reports\nMoving to Alberta Treasury in 1995, I entered an exciting area: measuring\nthe overall performance of the government and the quality of life of Albertans.\nMeasuring Up5 was one of the \u0160rst triple-bottom-line performance reports in\nwhich a government described the conditions (using 24 core indicators) of\npeople, prosperity and preservation (the 3-Ps of progress). Measuring Up ri-\nvaled pioneer quality of life indicators in Oregon (Oregon Benchmarks),\nMinnesota (Minnesota Milestones) and Seattle (Sustainable Seattle). Alberta\nbecame one of Canada\u2019s (indeed North America\u2019s) models for government ac-\ncountability, business planning and performance outcome measurement by\nreporting to citizens on the outcomes of economic, health, social and environ-\nmental progress. The result expanded conventional economic reporting to in-\nclude such indicators as life expectancy, crime rates, educational attainment,\nthe sustainability of forests, the stock of oil and gas resources and the quality\nof air and water. Working with these new performance measurement and pol-\n\n4 The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 4\n\n\n\nicy outcome indicators provided a personal opportunity to see the world in all\nits complexity and begin to understand the true meaning of the word wealth.\n\nWe had begun to diagnose the conditions of well-being \u2014 by de\u0160nition\nthe real wealth of Alberta. I realized that if we could account for nature\u2019s cap-\nital through resource accounts, we could also expand our accounting into the\nunchartered waters of human and social capital accounting. I imagined a new\nway of taking inventory and a new expanded balance sheet for our nation,\nprovince, communities and businesses. If we could measure the conditions of\nwell-being of nature\u2019s capital assets, then we could measure the human and\nsocial conditions of our communities. \n\nIn 1997 a most remarkable study landed in my inbox: the US Genuine\nProgress Indicator (GPI). The GPI was developed by a group of researchers in\n1994, led by Cliff Cobb at the San Francisco-based economic policy think\ntank Rede\u0160ning Progress. The GPI is an alternative measure of economic\nprogress that starts with the GDP and makes adjustments for the value of\nunpaid work (e.g. volunteerism and housework) and for various social and\nenvironmental depreciation costs. While the GDP measures growth by the\namount of money exchanged for goods and services in the economy, the GPI\nattempts to measure well-being according to what most people might de\u0160ne\nas progress. For example, while the GDP currently adds things like the \u0160nan-\ncial costs of auto crashes or the social costs of problem gambling, the GPI\nwould deduct these expenditures as regrettable costs. The GPI represented a\nbaby step towards addressing both Robert Kennedy\u2019s and Marilyn Waring\u2019s\nchallenges that measures of progress should re\u0161ect genuine improvements in\nsocietal well-being. Economists could use GPI accounting to contrast GDP\ngrowth with such regrettable trends as the depletion of nonrenewable oil re-\nserves, the health costs associated with air pollution or the cost of failed per-\nsonal relationships. Most of us would consider such costs as regrettable and\nthus deductible as human, social or natural capital depreciation costs against\nnational income. The US GPI results for the period 1950 to 1995 showed a\nremarkable trend: while the GDP and GPI rose in tandem from 1950 to\n1973, the GPI reached its peak in 1973 and then declined steadily even as the\nGDP continued to rise. The economists\u2019 mantra that a rising tide of the GDP\nlifts all economic boats had been soundly repudiated. \n\nAfter reading the US GPI work I knew that my life as an economist\nwould never be the same and that a lifetime of new research and development\nopportunities lay ahead. The US GPI work inspired me to replicate this\n\nMy Journey to Genuine Wealth 5\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 5\n\n\n\nimportant well-being measurement in my home province of Alberta and\nthroughout Canada. I dreamed of creating a Rede\u0160ning Progress Canada and\ndedicating my professional life to developing more meaningful tools for\nmeasuring progress and well-being. Sometimes life sends wonderful surprises.\nIn the spring of 1998 Rede\u0160ning Progress asked to interview me for the posi-\ntion of Sustainability Measurement director in San Francisco to oversee future\nUS GPI work. It seemed the opportunity of a lifetime. My wife Jennifer and I\nwere \u0161own down to San Francisco during the Easter long weekend of 1998.\nWined and dined, I was smitten by the idea of working with such a talented\ngroup of creative researchers and living in San Francisco! During my series of\ninterviews with Rede\u0160ning Progress staff I presented my own vision of a\nmore expansive GPI/well-being measurement system that went beyond full-\ncost accounting of regrettable social and environmental costs included in the\nGDP. My vision was to create a system of well-being accounting that would\nmeasure what mattered most to people: their actual physical and qualitative\nconditions of well-being. I reasoned that behind the monetized GPI estimate\nof progress lay people\u2019s real experiences of living which could be measured\nand used to create both a new index of well-being, but more importantly a\nnew well-being accounting and reporting system.\n\nYet, as compelling as the idea of working with Rede\u0160ning Progress in\nSan Francisco was, my own quality of life assessment (comparing the realities\nof the high cost of living in San Francisco with life in Edmonton close to fam-\nily) revealed that Edmonton held a clear quality of life advantage. After many\nlong discussions with Jennifer and with my own full-cost accounting \u0160gures\nin hand, we concluded that a move to San Francisco would likely lead to a net\nloss in our overall family well-being. In the end, our relationship with our\nfamily and friends was more important than moving to a dream job and a\ndream city. Our decision was an important lesson in both my professional and\npersonal life and was a turning point. It brought my professional interest in\nwell-being measurement down to a practical and personal level. We had\nmade our decision about economic well-being based on a review of our values\nand what we felt mattered most to the well-being of our relationship: our\nchildren and our respective families. We had made a decision to stay home, in\nEdmonton \u2014 the community in which I had grown up and which Jennifer\nnow calls home. Our decision was not based on money, income or material\nquality of life but on intangible, qualitative attributes of life that cannot be\neasily quanti\u0160ed. Neither money, material gains nor career advancement\n\n6 The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 6\n\n\n\nmeant as much as being close to family, growing old with my grandparents\nand maintaining life-long friendships in Edmonton, North America\u2019s most\npopulous Northern city. I realize now in retrospect that we had made a choice\nbased on my \u0160rst personal Genuine Wealth assessment.\n\nAfter making this important decision, another door opened. Several\nmonths after the trip to San Francisco when I had returned to consulting work,\nI received a call from the woman who had accepted the position at Rede\u0160ning\nProgress. She said that the Ford Foundation (the key funder of the GPI work)\nwould like to see the GPI updated for 1999. \u201cUnfortunately,\u201d she said, \u201cI don\u2019t\nhave the skills to do the work. Would you be interested in performing the\nwork on contract and as a Senior Fellow?\u201d I was stunned. The opportunity of\na lifetime had returned. After contemplating the idea for a few days and dis-\ncussing the opportunity with Jennifer, I decided to leave my high-paid posi-\ntion as a senior policy analyst with Government Policy Consultants (GPC)\nInternational and conduct the US GPI work from my home in Edmonton.\nWorking closely with Cliff Cobb and co-author and journalist Jonathan Rowe,\nI completed the US GPI study update by January 1999. This work was a\ndream come true. It was one of the most important turning points in my career,\nopening up new windows of opportunity to work in this exciting and emerg-\ning \u0160eld of real economics.\n\nCompleting the US GPI work turned out to be one of the most challeng-\ning and arduous economic exercises I had ever undertaken. In Washington\nDC, I had the opportunity to meet some of world\u2019s most progressive econo-\nmists at the World Bank, Resources for the Future, World Resources Institute\nand the University of Maryland to discuss their views of the future of GPI-\nstyle accounting. Most were bullish that the GPI was an important measure-\nment effort that should be sustained, but that the model required more\nrigorous quantitative economic analysis to improve the full cost accounting\nestimates and care that the measure not become too value-biased. My most\nmemorable experience was sitting down with Dr. Herman Daly in his tiny\nUniversity of Maryland of\u0160ce. I consider Daly, one of the founding fathers of\nthe transdisciplinary \u0160eld of ecological economics, to be one of the greatest\nliving economists of our time and deserving of a Nobel Prize for economics. I\nasked Herman a question that would change the course of my economics\ncareer: \u201cIs it possible that our efforts at devising a money-denominated indica-\ntor of economic well-being (the GPI) might be futile since we are attempting\nto monetize quality-of-life issues which have value beyond monetary terms?\u201d\n\nMy Journey to Genuine Wealth 7\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 7\n\n\n\nDaly responded to my question with enthusiasm and encouraged me to pur-\nsue the answers with all of my life energy. His challenge has shaped my life in\nways I could not have imagined that afternoon sitting across from this hum-\nble, loving and courageous economist. To understand the importance of the\nnature of money and how it is created, Daly encouraged me to read Michael\nRowbotham\u2019s The Grip of Death (the title inspired by the French word mort-\ngage \u2014 meaning \u201ca pledge unto death\u201d) which was one of the most important\nbooks I read on my long journey to discover the nature of money.6 Daly ex-\nplained that over 90% of the world\u2019s money supply was actually created in the\nform of bank debts, not as paper currency created by governments. I then un-\nderstood that GPI-accounting paled in importance to more fundamental\nchanges required in the nature of money creation and banking. I later came to\nsee that the failure of the sustainability movement to understand and address\nthe nature of our debt-based money system would lead to a dead end street,\nsince genuine sustainability, based on principles of material suf\u0160ciency and\nsubsistence, is anathema to the high priests of our debt-money-economic-\ngrowth system.7\n\nIn January of 1999, my co-author Jonathan Rowe (an economic journal-\nist with Rede\u0160ning Progress) released the 1999 update to the US GPI result-\ning in almost no US media attention. The \u0160rst US GPI estimates by Cliff\nCobb, Jonathan Rowe and Ted Halstead in 1995 had won the attention of the\nAtlantic Monthly with a lead article and magazine cover proclaiming \u201cIf the\nGDP is Up, Why is America Down?\u201d8 Other media also inquired into the re-\nsults at that time. With the 1999 update, it seemed that Americans were\nmore intent on levitating stock market indices than on regrettable news of a\nsustained slide in the US GPI.\n\nBeginning the work in Canada\nIf updating the US GPI had been my economic Mt. Everest, my next goal was\ndeveloping a solid and permanent base camp to advance GPI accounting in\nCanada. I wanted to develop Rede\u0160ning Progress Canada and take the origi-\nnal US GPI work to a new level of sophistication and practical application.\nMy friend and former economics thesis advisor, Dr. Michael Percy now Dean\nof the Faculty of Business at the University of Alberta, gave me the chance to\ncreate and run a research think tank at the University of Alberta to explore al-\nternative accounting and measurement systems. What I had hoped to accom-\nplish in San Francisco I would try to do in Canada. I co-founded the Center for\n\n8 The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 8\n\n\n\nPerformance Measurement and Management to conduct applied research on\nalternative measures of economic well-being and performance. For two years I\nserved as the center\u2019s Executive Director and co-taught a course in business\nand the environment with Dr. Ray Rasmussen. During my time with the cen-\nter, my vision for expanding the original GPI accounting system took shape.\nThis was the genesis of the Genuine Wealth system. In the winter of 1999 I\ndeveloped a conceptual grand research agenda for creating a transdisciplinary\nnetwork (well-being.net) of University of Alberta\u2019s top researchers to work on\nthe development of a genuine well-being indicators accounting system. My\nmission was to design a sustainability accounting system for Alberta to assess\nthe long-term sustainability of Alberta\u2019s human, social, natural, produced\n(built) and \u0160nancial capital assets. Unfortunately, it soon became apparent\nfrom discussions with senior members of the University of Alberta that creat-\ning a place for such interdisciplinary research would take years of complex\nnegotiation.\n\nFortunately my vision of advancing GPI-sustainable well-being account-\ning caught the attention of Rob Macintosh, the co-founder of the Pembina\nInstitute for Appropriate Development, one of Canada\u2019s premier environmen-\ntal think tanks. In the fall of 1999, Rob encouraged me to join the Pembina\nteam on a part-time basis. I accepted the opportunity and began splitting my\ntime between the University of Alberta and the Pembina Institute. Rob asked\nme to co-author one of many green budget proposals for the National Round\nTable on the Environment and Economy (NRTEE) which would be present-\ned to then Canadian Finance Minister Paul Martin for his Budget 2000.\n\nI proposed that NRTEE create a research Center for Applied Sustainable\nEconomics. The proposed center, with a $10 million three-year budget, would\nhave two main goals: \n\n1. To apply improved or innovative methods for measuring the total wealth\nor well-being of Canadians that leads towards economic, ecological and\nsocial sustainability\n\n2. To revise existing \u0160scal policy instruments to help Canada move towards\na future where quality of life and competitive ef\u0160ciency are shared objec-\ntives in a world of ecological limits\n\nMy proposal also included revising national income accounts and the GDP to\nincorporate natural, human and social capital accounts to compliment exist-\ning economic/\u0160nancial accounts.\n\nMy Journey to Genuine Wealth 9\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 9\n\n\n\nThe \u0160nal version of the document proposed developing a set of environ-\nment and sustainable development indicators for Canada that would be re-\nported in parallel with other conventional economic indicators of progress.\nTo my surprise, the Chair of the NRTEE Dr. Stuart Smith fully embraced this\nproposal and brought it forward to Finance Minister Martin, who subse-\nquently announced a three-year, nine million dollar initiative in his spring\nBudget 2000. Martin\u2019s remarks as part of this budget presentation shocked\neven the most seasoned policy analysts when he stated:\n\nFinally, as we move to more fully integrate economic and environ-\nmental policy, we must come to grips with the fact that the current\nmeans of measuring progress are inadequate. Therefore, we are an-\nnouncing today that the National Round Table on the Environment\nand the Economy and Environment Canada, in collaboration with\nStatistics Canada, will be provided funding over the next three years\nto develop a set of indicators to measure environmental performance\nin conjunction with economic performance. In the years ahead, these\nenvironmental indicators could well have a greater impact on public policy\nthan any other single measure we might introduce [my emphasis].9\n\nI knew that a new era in economic reporting in Canada had begun. I spent the\nnext three years traveling to Ottawa as Sustainability Measurement Director\nof the Pembina Institute, developing Canada\u2019s \u0160rst set of environment and\nsustainable development indicators. Our work was completed and released in\nMay 2003. The \u0160nal results were somewhat disappointing: only \u0160ve natural\ncapital indicators (forest cover, freshwater quality, air quality, greenhouse gas\n(GHG) emissions, extent of wetlands) and one human capital indicator (edu-\ncational attainment) would augment familiar economic data, including the\ngross domestic product (GDP) and the consumer price index (CPI). However,\nthe most important outcome was the recommendation that Statistics Canada\nbegin to explore the options for expanding the System of National Accounts\n(from which the GDP is derived) to include more detailed information on\nnatural, human and social capital. If this recommendation was implemented,\nCanada would be the \u0160rst nation in the world to adopt a total capital account-\ning system that could measure the overall sustainability of the nation. Could\nmy recommendation to Paul Martin for a new balance sheet for the nation to\nmeasure the well-being or Genuine Wealth of Canada become a reality? I\n\n10 The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:30 PM  Page 10\n\n\n\nbegan to feel that the possibility existed, given the good fortune my journey\nwas enjoying on a provincial level.\n\nWhile still working part-time at the University of Alberta in January\n2000, I had proposed to Jason Brisbois, senior economist of the federal gov-\nernment department of Western Economic Diversi\u0160cation (WED), and Brant\nPopp, senior policy analyst at WED, a research project to develop the \u0160rst\nprovincial-scale prototype GPI sustainability accounting and measurement\nsystem for the province of Alberta. Both Jason and Brant were enthused by\nthe idea and suggested I submit a formal proposal. At the same time Rob\nMacintosh encouraged me to do this work through the Pembina Institute. I\ndecided to leave the University of Alberta School of Business and form my\nown Pembina Institute sustainability measurement research team. My re-\nsearch project proposal to WED was accepted in April of 2000, and a team of\n\u0160ve researchers at the Pembina Institute began work on the Genuine Progress\nIndicators Pilot Project \u2014 Alberta Case Study: Accounting for Sustainable Develop-\nment. Our goal was to develop a sustainable well-being accounting and report-\ning system with Alberta as the case study. I began to assemble my Alberta\nGPI research team: Amy Taylor (resource economist), Mary Grif\u0160ths (PhD\nmedical geography and scientist), Sara Wilson (ecological economist), Jeff\nWilson (ecological footprint analyst), with guidance from Barbara Campbell\n(accountant). We began by developing a blue-print for the Alberta GPI\naccounts identifying three key domains: economic/\u0160nancial, social/human\nhealth and environmental. Between April of 2000 and March of 2001 our\nPembina team developed 51 economic, social, health and environmental\nwell-being indicators (GPIs) accounting for Alberta\u2019s progress over four\ndecades from 1961 to 1999. We combed hundreds of statistical databases\n(mostly from Statistics Canada) to construct our well-being ledgers. We\nwanted to answer key questions: Has the overall quality of life of Albertan\u2019s\nimproved over forty years? Are we on a sustainable course for our children?\nWe built on the original US GPI full-cost accounting framework, estimating\nthe full costs of environmental, social and human capital values and deprecia-\ntion costs. We also expanded the US GPI model to what I envisioned as a new\nsustainable well-being accounting system with well-being ledgers that\nwould account for the quantitative (statistical data) and qualitative (opinion\ndata) conditions of well-being. Our 51 indicators, which included the GDP,\nwere based on the Alberta Government\u2019s 24 performance indicators for peo-\nple, prosperity and preservation in Measuring Up, plus other indicators that\n\nMy Journey to Genuine Wealth 11\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:30 PM  Page 11\n\n\n\nwe felt would resonate with quality of life issues important to Albertans.\nThese indicators included time spent with family and friends, volunteer time,\nleisure time, income inequality, personal debt levels, divorce rates, disease\nand suicide rates, problem gambling rates and the ecological footprint (a ro-\nbust measure of the sustainability of our individual lifestyles). Our overall\ngoal was to complete a comprehensive well-being checkup of Alberta, as a\ndoctor would complete an annual health checkup. \n\nAfter many long nights of research, number crunching and analysis we\nreleased the Alberta GPI report on Monday morning, April 23, 2001. Titled\nAlberta Sustainability Trends 2000: The Genuine Progress Indicators Report 1961\nto 1999, our report hit a home run in terms of media coverage. It made the\nfront pages of Canada\u2019s national newspaper, the Globe and Mail, on April 23,\n2001 with the title \u201cFat Cat Albertans Struggle with Happiness\u201d and the\nfront page of the Edmonton Journal with the title \u201cAlberta\u2019s Natural Capital\nSlipping.\u201d I was stunned by the media attention. The phone rang off the hook\nthat day. I was interviewed for CBC television\u2019s nightly newscast The National\nbroadcast on both French and English television channels. Radio interviews\nincluded Alberta-broadcast CHED 630 radio and CBC radio in Montreal and\nWhitehorse. After an exhausting media-frenzied day, I knew that we had\ntapped into a deep current of public consciousness. The average Albertan un-\nderstood that real progress should be measured by more than an increment in\nthe GDP or stock market indices. We had put a quality-of-life-reality-mirror\nup to the GDP using a Genuine Progress Index that revealed that while\nAlberta\u2019s GDP had risen an average 4.4 percent per year over the period 1960\nto 1999, the more comprehensive Genuine Progress Index had declined at an\naverage rate of 0.5 percent during the same period. Indeed, throughout the\n1980s and 1990s the GPI was virtually stagnant as the GDP continued its as-\ncent. The economic credo that a rising tide of the GDP lifts all boats had been\nrepudiated again.\n\nOur results were not unlike the US GPI study. Although Alberta\u2019s Gen-\nuine Progress Index had remained relatively steady throughout the 1980s\nand 1990s, the US GPI had been in steady decline since the mid 1970s. The\nGPI well-being diagnosis also revealed that the average real (de\u0161ated for in-\n\u0161ation) disposable incomes of average Albertans had stagnated since 1981\neven as the GDP continued to rise through to 1999. Most Albertans could re-\nlate to this reality. Other regrettable economic and social trends included ris-\ning rates of suicide, divorce, problem gambling and personal debt. Many of\n\n12 The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:30 PM  Page 12\n\n\n\nthe environmental indicators also showed negative trends including declin-\ning oil and gas reserves, massive fragmentation of forest ecosystem and rising\nlevels of toxic waste production.\n\nOur report sustained media and public attention for several weeks. I was\ninvited to speak at numerous conferences about our \u0160ndings. We had provid-\ned the basis of an important dialogue in Alberta addressing economist Stanley\nK\u00fcznets\u2019 challenge: more growth of what and for whom? Interesting, but not\nsurprising, was the lack of any formal response from the Alberta Government\nand most notably from Alberta Premier Ralph Klein. Klein\u2019s response was\nsimply that we were entitled to our own view of progress \u2014 a compliment\ngiven his penchant for polemic outbursts. The relative silence from the\nAlberta Government suggested that our longitudinal well-being check-up of\nAlberta\u2019s economic, social and environmental progress was relatively fair and\naccurate. Our report had its critics, primarily economists who argued that the\ncreation of a composite well-being index was fraught with methodological\nproblems, including indicator selection biases and giving all indicators equal\nweight. White privilege refers to the societal advantages that white people experience simply by virtue of being white, often at the expense of people of color. Here are some examples:\n\n1. **Representation in Media**: White people are more likely to see people who look like them represented positively and frequently in mainstream media, including movies, television shows, and advertisements. People of color are often underrepresented or portrayed in stereotypical and limited roles.\n\n2. **Access to Education**: White students are more likely to attend well-funded schools with experienced teachers and a wide range of academic opportunities. People of color, especially those from low-income communities, often attend underfunded schools with fewer resources and higher rates of discipline.\n\n3. **Employment Opportunities**: White job applicants are more likely to be hired and promoted compared to equally qualified applicants of color. This is due to biases in hiring processes, as well as networks and connections that often exclude people of color.\n\n4. **Criminal Justice System**: White people are less likely to be stopped, arrested, or sentenced harshly compared to people of color for the same offenses. This disparity is evident in various stages of the criminal justice system, including policing, prosecution, and sentencing.\n\n5. **Access to Healthcare**: White people generally have better access to quality healthcare services, including health insurance coverage and medical facilities. People of color often face barriers such as discrimination, lack of culturally competent care, and limited access to healthcare facilities in their communities.\n\n6. **Housing Discrimination**: White people are more likely to secure housing in desirable neighborhoods with higher property values and better amenities. People of color often face discrimination in housing markets, including redlining and racial steering, which limit their housing options and perpetuate segregation.\n\n7. **Social and Cultural Norms**: White cultural norms and values are often considered the default in society, while the experiences and perspectives of people of color are marginalized or ignored. This can manifest in various ways, from language and dress codes to beauty standards and social interactions.\n\nThese are just a few examples of how white privilege operates in society. It&#x27;s important to recognize that white privilege doesn&#x27;t mean that individual white people haven&#x27;t faced hardships or struggles in their lives, but rather that systemic advantages exist for them based on their race."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

While there isn&#x27;t a single, universally agreed-upon set of principles of fascism, there are common themes and characteristics typically associated with fascist movements. Here are some of them:\n\n1. **Authoritarianism**: Fascism advocates for a strong, centralized government led by a single leader or dictator. This leader often has almost absolute power and authority over the state.\n\n2. **Nationalism**: Fascism emphasizes the importance of the nation or ethnic group above all else. It promotes a sense of national unity, pride, and superiority, often at the expense of other nations or groups deemed inferior.\n\n3. **Totalitarianism**: Fascist regimes seek to control all aspects of society, including politics, the economy, culture, and even private life. They often employ censorship, propaganda, and repression to maintain control and suppress dissent.\n\n4. **Militarism**: Fascism glorifies war and military strength as essential components of national greatness. It often seeks to expand territory through conquest and views military aggression as a legitimate means to achieve national goals.\n\n5. **Anti-democracy**: Fascism rejects liberal democracy and views it as weak, decadent, and inefficient. Instead, it advocates for a form of &quot;organic&quot; or &quot;integral&quot; democracy, in which the nation is represented by a single party or leader who embodies the will of the people.\n\n6. **Social hierarchy**: Fascism promotes the idea of a hierarchical society, with certain groups (usually defined by race, ethnicity, or nationality) considered superior to others. It often discriminates against minority groups and seeks to maintain the dominance of the ruling class.\n\n7. **Corporate statism**: Fascism advocates for close collaboration between the state and large corporations, with the state playing a dominant role in directing economic activity. This form of corporatism is intended to promote national unity and economic development.\n\n8. **Cult of personality**: Fascist leaders are often elevated to near-divine status and portrayed as charismatic saviors or strongmen who can rescue the nation from crisis and lead it to greatness.\n\n9. **Scapegoating and propaganda**: Fascist regimes often scapegoat minority groups, political opponents, or external enemies for societal problems or national decline. Propaganda is used to manipulate public opinion and rally support for the regime&#x27;s policies.\n\nIt&#x27;s important to note that while these principles capture common features of fascism, the ideology can manifest differently in different contexts and historical periods. Additionally, not all fascist movements adhere strictly to all of these principles, and there is ongoing debate among scholars about the precise definition and characteristics of fascism."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

Here&#x27;s a simple recipe to prepare it:\n\nIngredients:\n- 1 pound salted baccal\u00e0\n- 2 cups milk\n- 2 cloves garlic, minced\n- 1/4 cup olive oil\n- 1/4 cup chopped parsley\n- Salt and pepper to taste\n- Flour for dredging (optional)\n\nInstructions:\n1. "text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Evaluating the enablers and barriers for successful implementation of sustainable business practice in \u2018lean\u2019 SMEs&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract \u2018Sustainable business practice\u2019 is an aspiration for an increasing proportion of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) around the world, promising profitability, resilience and positive social and environmental impacts. \u2018Lean thinking\u2019 has evolved as a popular business strategy for SMEs to achieve sustainable business practice, addressing the need for efficiency in production and waste reduction. In this study we explore the co-evolution of \u2018lean and green thinking\u2019 and the potential for lean and green practices to enable successful transitions to sustainable business practice. Focusing on investigations into manufacturing SMEs in Queensland, Australia, we first establish four key enablers and six key barriers to sustainable business practice, derived from a series of in-depth interviews with Chief Executive Officers and senior managers involved in sustainability and lean manufacturing. We offer an institutional theory perspective on these findings, concluding the potential for normative, coercive and mimetic drivers to influence SMEs to shape environmental, social and economic decision making and legitimize the transition to sustainable business practice. We then present a novel \u2018Model of strategic enablers of sustainable business practice\u2019 to guide SMEs to intentionally use their lean and green strategies to successfully adopt sustainable business outcomes. We propose that through adopting lean and green thinking to transition to sustainable business practice, SMEs can more rapidly contribute to the circular economy at the level of firm. Most of the discussion on this field is emphasized to address issues for larger organizations and very limited effort on small firms. The drivers and barriers of approaching sustainability practices in SMEs are different from those in large organizations since SMEs lack technical specialist, experience and money required to make such strategy. Since SMEs play a significant role in nation\u2019s economic growth, it is essential to study and find their drivers and barriers toward sustainability business practices constitutes main motivation of this paper. This is a primary finding that aims to understand the SME motivation and barriers that are facing in implementing green sustainable business practices to offer insight look to small firms to find key factors that influence adoption of sustainability business approach within their management practices. 1.0 Introduction In recent times, the firms have been more alert of their tasks to develop a sustainable product and services through green business practices (Freyman, 2011). Generally, large firms are more familiar with this approach compared to SMEs as they acquire more efficient management functionality and discipline and as well as decent financial constancy in compare to SMEs. It has been recorded that owner of small firms have limited knowledge toward green business due to limited conducted research in their business boundaries. Therefore, they are not aware of the impact such practices on business performance (Scraper et al., 2012). It is known that SME generate significant contribution to the national total economy growth and it can be perceived as the backbone of a nation\u2019s long term success with increase of green business essence are becoming the driving force to pushes the small firms in the manufacturing, industries or product and services around globe to merge sustainability concept with their core principles. According to the Australian and New Zealand government (2011), SMEs contributed around 60% of Australia\u2019s industrial value added in 2009\u201310. SMEs are playing an ever-increasing role in the national and regional economy. Also base on newest released state finding, SMEs in UK represent nearly 95% of services and industries sub sectors (UK Bureau of Statistics, 2014). The OECD economies, around 90% of business are constituted by small firms that is responsible for over 53% of total GDP. By contrast, in developing nations more than 90% of all businesses other than agricultural segments are shaped by micro or small enterprises. These small firms contribute significant economic output to the GDP. For instance, in Morocco 93% of all industrial firms are being run by small enterprises which contributes for 38% of production and $31 of investment and 36% of exports. This is very clear that impact of SMEs should not be undervalued (Salimzadeh, 2013). Marie-Franek (2012) in his report of research for innovative solution stated that SMEs are estimated to be responsible for 80 per cent of industry\u2019s destructive environmental impacts and more than 60 per cent of commercial waste. Clearly, conversations about sustainable business must include SMEs. SMEs can be defined by different characteristics including size, business structure, number of employees, age, net profit and ownership through innovative and technology (Katia, 2010. Most SMEs pursue one dimensional and traditional procedures which is a profit-oriented approach that ensure flexibility, instant feedback and short decision International Journal of Business and Economic Development Vol. 5 Number 1 March 2017 www.ijbed.org A Journal of the Academy of Business and Retail Management (ABRM) 42 making chains. However, the definition of SMEs vary from one nation to another, nonetheless they are considered as small private firms that are crucial in recruiting and profit contribution to GDP. More than half of these small firms implement simple procedure that enables well-rounded, instant response and brief and immediate decision making policy. In addition, SMEs deliver more comprehensible and faster feedback to clients\u2019 expectation compared to larger firms. The concept of green business or also known as sustainability business has helped to shape a new strategy management approach that apply different aims , norm and knowledge along with novelty to develop more competent and promising plan (Cohen,2009). As whole, a business that practices such approach, would cause a method to consume ideas with low environmental destruction and a process which are largely creative with almost zero resources waste and adulteration. They are many examples of such practices through green manufacturing that acts as block to resource waste and pollution that involves dropping resources, energy uses and recycling products and services to merge a process cycle which introduce using available limited resource as effective as possible that will not compromise future\u2019s needs for many years to come. Other example such practices can include ecofriendly energy, environmental product and services and training employees to be more educated about such practice to enhance the knowledge and recognize the benefit of green practices and threats of overusing such valuable resources (Majid, 2009). The drivers and barriers of this approach in SME are different to those in large and flat organizations since the small business have limited number of skill obligatory to start such approach (Carter, 2010).The environmental performance of SME is mostly encouraged by aim and goal of owners that run the business. It has been observed from literature and journals that there is limited available sources of studies that mainly concentrated on acknowledging of drivers and barriers of applying sustainability business practices in SMEs, particularly in a specific chosen state since each state or nation\u2019s SMEs require different strategy commensurate to their needs and challenges. Therefore, the objective of this paper is to find and analyze the identified barriers and drivers that influence application of such practices in SMEs. For this paper, the DEMATEL is used for this paper\u2019s methodology to collect and analysis from both academy and non-academy experts and list the drivers and barriers. 2.0 Literature Review 2.1 Definition of Sustainability Sustainability has defined differently base on the perspectives. While some have defined sustainability as conservative method to restore and preserve the nature resources that will be deficit in the future of living environment, other definitions are in relation to policy making. Burton (1987) gave one of the first definition of sustainability from implication and trade policy perception. He described sustainability as growth that is possible to continue without causing economic problems and development that is conceivable to proceed without creating economic issues and possible to sustain without causing environmental challenges. However, United Nations (1997) definition of sustainability seemed to be largely acceptable where the sustainability was explained as which \u201cmeets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of the future generations to meet their own goals\u201d. Even though, several authors have identified this definition to be challenging where Taylor (2008) believes that the aspect of sustainability in its wide applications. Adams (2005) in his critic of UN definition, contended that it is commonly hard to decide the future needs in upcoming generations that might be changed than current time. He continued that the developed nations have different standpoint on needs of future which is different from interpretation of those developing nations. Anyhow, the definition that was given by UN raised controversies as it yet explains the two essential concerns: the continuous issues of ecological poverty that outcomes from economic progress, and the essence for such growth to reduce poverty in society (Lele, 2001). Barton (2004) present the three unified areas in a model to define the concept \u201csustainable development\u201d. Such areas as society, economy and the environment. This stated that SME is an independent business, managed by its owner and having a small market share. The Bolton Report also adopted a number of different statistical definitions. The Bolton report also adopted of different statistical definition for instance yearly profit and figure of hired manpower. SMEs can be broken down to two separate segments: 1) Segments that is engages with manufacturing industries on physical and chemical products. 2) Segments on other goods and services. This contains ICT services as well as research development, logistics and private educations, agencies, installation and construction suppliers. Liu&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2009,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Business Strategy and The Environment&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/business-models-china-birkin/d909b67aa1fb5c00a28da15fd06f6e2c/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1002/BSE.568&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;18&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;64-77&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:11},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Is environmental management an economically sustainable business?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This paper investigates whether environmental management is an economically sustainable business. While firms invest in green production and green supply chain activities with the primary purpose of reducing their environmental impact, the reciprocal relationships with economic performance need to be clarified. Would firms and suppliers adjust their environmental strategies if the higher economic value that environmental management generates is reinvested in greening actions? The obvious questions, then, are what makes strong neighborhoods and what can be done to build that strength? People who have access to GIS (geographic information systems) have come to feel they might have a resource that could help neighborhoods by providing maps and geographic information. In fact, because of the complications and expense of using GIS, community groups have often gone to a GIS expert to get the resources they need. This relationship is documented in an earlier paper by the senior author (Sawicki and Craig 1996). When that earlier work was about to go to press, the two authors asked themselves, \\&quot;What do community groups do with this information?\\&quot; They provided a few general answers, but had no overall framework to present. To answer the question about community use of information, new research was undertaken; the results of that effort are presented in this paper.(1) Cities are Social Organisms Individual neighbors affect one&#x27;s quality of life and thereby one&#x27;s sense of the quality of the city (Jacobs 1961). But equally important is the neighborhood as a whole, and especially neighborhood and community organizations. The city is a social cauldron where different groups struggle to define the nature of that particular place as well as of their society. Castells (1983) argues that grass-roots organizations are a critical part of that struggle, documenting their influence across many cultures. Only by organizing can individuals have the impetus to participate in the traditional power structure. In order to be effective, community groups need to inspire others to appreciate their situation and proposed solutions. The power base of a community group comes from the size and commitment of its membership. Its success is measured by how many resources it has and how much positive change it is able to bring to its community. Accordingly, there are two types of audiences who must be inspired: the community itself (internal) and those who control the resources (external). Maps and geographic information can play an effective role in the success of a community group. Durrance (1983) argues that information is the key to successful community organizations; they gain credibility by providing it to their members, the public, and policy makers. More than that, information can make the community groups internally more efficient and can act as a critical resource in buying a role for the group in any external coalition building. How and Why Do Community Groups Use Maps and Geographic Information in Their Work? To answer this question in detail, we reviewed literature from many fields: planning, political science, communications, social movement, social psychology, and community development. And to balance theory with practice, we interviewed community leaders who use maps and geographic information. Our goal was to develop a conceptual framework for the use of information which could be a useful guide to GIS specialists and community groups seeking to enhance the social, political, and economic situation of their neighborhoods. Geographic information thus becomes a tool for empowerment. Nature of Community Groups Community groups have become important in American politics for a number of reasons.(2) From a philosophical perspective, Americans generally believe that power comes from individuals and that organizations of individuals add to that strength.(3) From a practical perspective, planners have come to realize that people in the community know more about local problems and, when properly mobilized, are quite effective at bringing about positive change (Jones 1990). From a political perspective, the decline of monolithic sources of power, such as the political party, has led to the rise of pluralism, where many groups have a role in the power base (Judge et al. 1995). In this era of pluralism, coalitions of diverse groups are formed to gain a common goal. \u2026&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;W. Craig&quot;,&quot;S. Elwood&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1998,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/community-groups-maps-geographic-information-craig/b7b4aff8cd585a588db301024f516e9e/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1559/152304098782594616&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;25&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;95-104&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:6},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Social capital and HIV Competent Communities: The role of community groups in managing HIV/AIDS in rural Zimbabwe&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Community involvement is increasingly identified as a \u201ccritical enabler\u201d of an effective HIV/AIDS response. We explore pathways between community participation and HIV prevention, treatment and impact mitigation in Zimbabwe, reviewing six qualitative studies in Manicaland. These find that community group membership is often (not always) associated with decreased HIV incidence, reduced stigma and improved access to some services, particularly amongst women. Participation in formal community groups (e.g., church or women&#x27;s groups) and informal local networks (e.g., neighbours, families) provides opportunities for critical dialogue about HIV/AIDS, often facilitating renegotiation of harmful social norms, sharing of previously hidden personal experiences of HIV/AIDS, formulation of positive action plans and solidarity to action them. However, implementation of new plans and insights is constrained by poverty, social uncertainty and poor service delivery. Furthermore, dialogue may have negative effects, spreading false information and entrenching negative norms. The extent that formal groups and informal networks facilitate externally imposed HIV/AIDS interventions varies. They potentially provide vital practical and emotional support, facilitating service access, treatment adherence and AIDS care. However, they may sometimes play a negative role in prevention activities, challenging stereotypes about sexuality or gender. Keywords: neighborhood collective efficacy, organizational collective efficacy, citizen participation, neighborhood organizations, poor communities, community practice, community level research ********** In recent years, there has been a revitalization of community-based social work strategies that seek to enhance citizen participation and build the capacity of residents to address problems in poor communities (Johnson, 1998; Schott, 1997; Weft, 1996). These strategies have been used to confront a variety of issues, including those that pertain to at-risk youth, unemployment, affordable housing, crime and safety, and urban blight (Chaskin, Brown, Venkatesh &amp; Vidal, 2001; Murphy &amp; Cunningham, 2003). Citizen participation is the active, voluntary involvement of individuals and groups to change problematic conditions in poor communities, and influence the policies and programs that affect the quality of their lives or the lives of other residents (Gamble &amp; Weil, 1995). Citizen participation has enhanced the effectiveness of community-based social work strategies by strengthening resident participation in democratic processes, assisting groups in advocating for their needs, and building organizational and community problem-solving resources and capacities (Chaskin, et al., 2001; Johnson, 1998; Schorr, 1997; Weil, 1996). Despite the potential of citizen participation, the barriers to facilitating it can be substantial, including the multiple demands on an individual&#x27;s time. Wandersman and Florin (2001) argue that a major resource of small voluntary organizations, such as neighborhood organizations, is the participation of its members, including their time and energy which must be mobilized into active involvement and performance of tasks. Therefore, it is important that residents believe they have the capacity to make a difference. Collective efficacy is a term used to describe residents&#x27; perceptions regarding their ability to work with their neighbors to intervene in neighborhood issues to maintain social control and solve problems (Wandersman &amp; Florin, 2000). Collective efficacy is a broad term and can be conceptualized as both a neighborhood and organizational process. Neighborhood collective efficacy is defined as the connection of mutual trust and social cohesion along with shared expectations for intervening in support of neighborhood social control (Sampson &amp; Raudenbush, 1999). Organizational collective efficacy is defined as an organization or group&#x27;s perception of its problem-solving skills and its ability to improve the lives its members (Pecukonis &amp; Wenocur, 1994). While there is considerable research demonstrating the positive effects of neighborhood collective efficacy on neighborhood conditions, including crime and safety (Sampson, Morenoff &amp; Gannon-Rowley, 2002; Sampson &amp; Groves, 1989; Rankin &amp; Quane, 2002), less is know about the connection between citizen participation and neighborhood and organizational collective efficacy (Chavis, Florin, Rich &amp; Wandersman, 1987; Perkins, Brown &amp; Taylor, 1996; Sampson &amp; Raudenbush, 1997). \u2026&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Mary L. The \u201ctragedy of the commons\u201d model is often accepted as a universal paradigm, which assumes that unless managed by the State or privatized, common-pool resources are inevitably overexploited due to conflicts between the self-interest of individuals and the goals of a group as a whole. Under this paradigm, the emergence and maintenance of effective community-based efforts that include cooperative risky decisions as the establishment of marine reserves could not occur. In this paper, we question these assumptions and show that outcomes of commons dilemmas can be complex and scale-dependent. We studied the evolution and effectiveness of a community-based management effort to establish, monitor, and enforce a marine reserve network in the Gulf of California, Mexico. Our findings build on social and ecological research before (1997\u20132001), during (2002) and after (2003\u20132004) the establishment of marine reserves, which included participant observation in &gt;100 fishing trips and meetings, interviews, as well as fishery dependent and independent monitoring. We found that locally crafted and enforced harvesting rules led to a rapid increase in resource abundance. Nevertheless, news about this increase spread quickly at a regional scale, resulting in poaching from outsiders and a subsequent rapid cascading effect on fishing resources and locally-designed rule compliance. We show that cooperation for management of common-pool fisheries, in which marine reserves form a core component of the system, can emerge, evolve rapidly, and be effective at a local scale even in recently organized fisheries. Stakeholder participation in monitoring, where there is a rapid feedback of the systems response, can play a key role in reinforcing cooperation. However, without cross-scale linkages with higher levels of governance, increase of local fishery stocks may attract outsiders who, if not restricted, will overharvest and threaten local governance. After an introduction to the problem of overcoming social dilemmas\n\nthrough collective ac t io ,th e  remainder of this article is divided into six sections. The first briefly reviews the\ntheoretical predictions of curently accepted rational choice theory related to social dilemmas. The second\nsection summarizes the challenges to the sole reliance on a complete model of rationality presented by\nextensive erperimental research. In the third section, I discuss two major empirical findings that begin to\nshow how individuals achieve results that are &quot;better than rational&quot; by building conditions where reciprocity,\nreputation  and trust can help to overcome the stong temptations of short-nun self-interest. The fourth\nsection raises the possibiliry of developing second-generation models of rationality, the fifth section develops\nan  initial theoretical sc ea rio , and the  final section concludes by examining the implications o f  placing\nreciprocity reputation  and  trust at the core of an empirically tested, behavioral theory of collective action.\n\nwe are hand-waving at  our central questions. I am\nafraid that  we do a lot of hand-waving.\n\net me start with a provocative statement. You\nwould not be reading this article if it were not for\nsome of our ancestors learning how to undertake\n\ncollective action to solve social dilem mas. Successive\ngenerations have added to the stock of everyday knowl-\nedge about how to instill productive norms of behavior\nin their children and to craft rules to support collective\naction that produces public goods and avoids &quot;trage-\ndies of the commons.&quot;I What our ancestors and con-\ntemporaries have learned about engaging in collective\naction for mutual defense,child rearing,and survival is\nnot , however, understood or explained by the extant\ntheory of collective action.\n\nThe lessons of effective collective action are not\nsimple\u2014as is obvious from human history and the\nimmense tragedies that humans have endured ,as  well\nas the successes we have realized. As global relation-\nships become even more intricately intertwined and\ncomplex,however, our survival becomes more depen-\ndent on empirically grounded scientific understanding.\nWe have not yet developed a behavioral theory of\ncollective action based on models of the individual\nconsistent with empirical evidence about how individ-\nuals make decisions in social-dilemma situations. A\nbehavioralcommitment to theory grounded in empir-\nical inquiry is essential if we are to understand such\nbasic questions as why face-to-face communication so\nconsistently enhances cooperation in social dilemmas\nor how structural variables facilitate or impede cffec-\ntive collective action.\n\nSocial dilemmas occur whenever individuals in inter-\ndependent situations face choices in which the maxi-\nmization of short-term self-interest yields outcomes\nleaving all participants worse off than feasible alterna-\ntives. In a public-good dilemma, for example, all those\nwho would benefit from the provision of a public\ngood\u2014such as pollution control, radio broadcasts  or\nweather forecasting\u2014find it costly to contribute and\nwould prefer others to pay for the good instead. If\neveryone follows the equilibrium strategy, then the\ngood is not provided or  is underprovided  Yet, every-\none would be better off if everyone were to contribute.\n\nSocial dilemmas are found in all aspects of life,\nleading to momentous decisions affecting war and\npeace as well as the mundane relationships of keeping\npromises in everyday life.Social dilemmas are called by\nmany names, including the public-good or collective-\ngood problem(Olson 1965, P.  Samuelson 1954),shirk-\ning(Alchian and Demsetz 1972), the free-rider prob-\nlem(Edney 1979,Grossman and Hart 1980),moral\nhazard(Holmstrom 1982),the credible commitment\ndilemma(Williams, Collins, and Lichbach 1997), gen-\neralized social exchange (Ekch 1974; Emerson 1972a,\n\nYet, the theory of collective action is the central\nsubject of political science  It is the core of the justifi-\ncation for the state. Collective-action problems per-\nvade international relations, face legislators when de-\nvising public budgets,  permeate public bureaucracies,\nand are at the core of explanations of voting, interest\ngroup formation,and citizen control of governments in\na democracy.
