I remember receiving calls from perplexed colleagues\nacross America who questioned my use of the word \u201cinvestment\u201d in the subtitle\u2014par-\nticularly in the same breath with my rhapsodic approach to philanthropy. Then, and\nnow, I see no contradiction. And, over the last eight years, the idea of \u201cinvestment\u201d has\nbeen the take-f ire trend in philanthropy. Social investment is understood, sought, and\nwelcomed. Volunteer \u201ctool kits\u201d for campaigns list \u201cinvestment opportunities.\u201dThe idea\nis no longer dissonant with the values premise of giving. Indeed, we have seen how the\ninvestment approach to community building through philanthropy has been the for-\nmula for increasing success.\n\nThe other principle I advanced in 1997 was the need for innovation. I stand today\neven more f irmly behind that notion. Where I see success both in the United States and\nabroad, it is because of innovation and creativity. Where I see failure, it is from the\nopposite behavior: unwillingness to change, the creation of internal and external silos\nwithin organizations and the sector, the resistance to taking the best ideas from the busi-\nness sector and applying them to our organizations.The absence of shared vision in com-\nmunities and organizations continues to inhibit the realization of our sector\u2019s power.\n\nWe are in many ways the most powerful sector. Not the largest, but the most power-\nful. Rooted in community trust and meeting clear and pressing needs, we make a pro-\nfound dif ference and, in the words of Robert Payton,\u201cease human suffering and enhance\nhuman potential\u201d as no other community resources can. Our universities, schools, hospi-\ntals, arts and cultural centers, human and social services organizations, environmental\nservices and other organizations help determine the quality of society and life and\nadvance the ideas of personal and community fulf illment. Unhampered (we hope!) by\ngovernment\u2019s layered bureaucracy and freed from the pressure of purely bottom line\naccountability of corporations, we can be nimble as we assess, respond, reach out, accom-\nplish, evaluate, grow, and have an ever-expanding impact.\n\nPreface to the Second Edition\n\nfm.qxd (i-xx)  3/3/05  3:04 PM  Page x\n\n\n\nRevising Beyond Fundraising has given me the gift of time to step back and ref lect on\nour sector today, at the beginning of the twenty-f irst century. I remain bullish. Recent\neconomic twists and turns and global events caused some small setbacks in fundraising\nbut strengthened our sense of mission. And that, after all, is what we are about.\n\nBeyond Fundraising: What It Means\n\nBecause this book is written for volunteers and staf f people working in a sector that is\nbased on the measurable success of its fundraising, the title may seem odd.The principle\nis simple: To go beyond fundraising, organizations must do more than fund raise. They\nmust also:\n\n\u2022 Believe and practice the principle that development is a comprehensive process of\nwhich fundraising is a pivotal part.\n\n\u2022 Understand that development is the series of deliberate activities by which we\ninvolve and retain funders in a donor-investor relationship with our organizations.\n\n\u2022 Give up the idea that \u201cdevelopment\u201d is synonymous with fundraising, the series of\napproaches to prospects and donors (direct mail, phone appeals, fundraising events,\nfall campaigns, winter campaigns) that yield revenues and donors from year to year.\nDevelopment is much bigger than fundraising. And fundraising alone is not enough.\n\nThe Need Continues to Grow\n\nThe need for the nonprof it sector to go \u201cbeyond fundraising\u201d and to understand and\napply development principles continues to grow. Increased competition among funders\nand a higher level of sophistication among donors have changed the nature of philan-\nthropy, development, and fundraising.\n\nOnce viewed as needy institutions to which people gave out of a sense of obligation,\nnonprof its now f ind they are being evaluated against dif ferent and tougher criteria\nbased on their own f inancial and community performance and their capacity to meet\ndonor needs. This shift in expectations requires organizations to practice the longer\nterm process of development; to go beyond fundraising.\n\nThe Origin of Beyond Fundraising and \nthe Basis for Its Revision\n\nAlthough I have written several other books since Beyond Fundraising was f irst published,\nthis book embodies my core beliefs and has been a continuous writing project for nearly\na decade. Many of its principles and strategies formed the basis of my f irst workshop\nwhen I began my consulting career. \u201cPutting Away the Tin Cup\u201d was, starting in 1987,\nmy \u201csignature seminar\u201d and was given for more than a decade to boards of trustees, other\nvolunteers, and staf f members of hundreds of not-for-prof it organizations in the United\nStates, Canada,Australia, the United Kingdom, and western Europe.\n\npreface xi\n\nfm.qxd (i-xx)  3/3/05  3:04 PM  Page xi\n\n\n\nThe primary purpose of \u201cPutting Away the Tin Cup\u201d workshops was to raise the\ncomfort level of board and staf f members as they raised money for nonprof it organiza-\ntions. It challenged old notions about fundraising. The workshop introduced new con-\ncepts and new ideas that allowed organizations to position themselves more positively in\ntheir communities. These same ideas have also guided my consultation with scores of\norganizations, have grown out of and informed my more than 20 years of teaching with\nThe Fund Raising School and other organizations, and they are the basis of this book.\nImportantly, I was a good listener at those sessions. I heard what volunteers and profes-\nsionals were saying about the obstacles and challenges they faced, and I was heartened by\ntheir successes. I still am. And in my own volunteer work with Stanford University and\nserving on boards of other organizations, I saw things from the perspective of the busy\nvolunteer who wants time, tools, and training and to be a partner for change.\n\nOver the years, my insights have sharpened to ref lect the experience and needs of the\nthousands of volunteer and staf f leaders with whom I have worked. These leaders have\nrepresented many places and institutions: public television across America, a national\ndomestic violence policy and education organization headquartered in San Francisco, a\nuniversity in England, a library in Paris, a leukemia foundation in Australia, a land trust\nin California, a technical institute in New Zealand, a preparatory school in Seattle, a\nmedical center near Los Angeles, a children\u2019s hospital in Canada, a church organization\nin Sweden, opera companies in New York and San Francisco, orchestras from across\nAmerica, and museums in New Mexico, Colorado, and France. Although these organi-\nzations dif fer, and the volunteer and staf f roles vary, the concerns expressed by clients\nand workshop attendees have many common threads:\n\n\u2022 Fear of rejection and a reluctance to be viewed as beggars as their principal reasons\nfor feeling uncomfortable with fundraising \n\n\u2022 Worry about asking too often, and wanting strategies for asking more ef fectively \n\n\u2022 Weariness of the relentless cycle of fundraising activities that they must pursue to\ngenerate revenues for their programs, and wanting to know how to cultivate and\nretain donors by building relationships with them\n\n\u2022 Enthusiasm about their organizations and their own capacity to make a dif ference\nin their communities \n\n\u2022 An eagerness to learn how to position their organizations in their communities as\nthe constructive, vital, and important organizations they are \n\nPrincipal Concepts\n\nThe principal concepts in this book are the \u201caha\u201d ideas that have been formed from\nthese common needs and tested in these workshops and consultations. To go beyond\nfundraising, nonprof its need to:\n\n\u2022 Position themselves as organizations that meet needs, not as organizations that have\nneeds\n\nxii preface\n\nfm.qxd (i-xx)  3/3/05  3:04 PM  Page xii\n\n\n\n\u2022 Know that a gift to them is really a gift through them into the community\n\n\u2022 Focus on program results, not just on f inancial goals\n\n\u2022 Remember that the process of asking and giving is based in shared values \n\n\u2022 View our organizations, and encourage others to perceive them, as vital additions\nto communities whose services and enhancements must be balanced and strong\n\n\u2022 Engage nonprof it leaders and donors at all levels in a process that will convert them\nto donor-investors, committed to a long-term relationship based on shared values\nand vision\n\n\u2022 Position all contributions to nonprof it organizations as social investments and all\ncontributors as donor-investors\n\n\u2022 See the process of revenue generation and constituency involvement as a much\nlarger, inclusive, and energizing process called development.\n\nThe Breakthrough Innovation\n\nOrganizations try new fundraising tactics but do not see they still lack the development\nframework that will create a lasting base of donor-investors. They seek innovative strate-\ngies for increasing revenues: the event no one has tried, the cleverly (or emotionally)\ncrafted mailing that will survive the 15-second initial exposure test and result in a f irst-\ntime gift, or hiring the best possible \u201cfundraiser\u201d (as they persist in inappropriately\ncalling development professionals). None of these strategies is enough to bring a consis-\ntent and stable base of funding to an organization without the principal innovation that\ngoes beyond fundraising and inspires development.\n\nThe innovation that has the most singular impact on all organizations with which I\nhave worked during my years as a consultant and teacher to the philanthropic sector is\nthis: an innovation in attitude about the entire fundraising process, one that properly puts\nit into the larger context of development and philanthropy. Only then does true innova-\ntion occur. Attitudes shift. One person wrote, after a particularly rigorous workshop,\u201cI\nwill now feel proud to ask for money for our college.\u201d\n\nInnovation requires a willingness to set aside old ideas. A certain entrepreneurial spirit\nmust prevail; there must be a willingness to risk. Courage is fundamental and conf idence\nis critical. The enviable mystique that surrounds those who are successful at fundraising\nis nothing more, in my experience, than the attitude those individuals have about the\nprocess:\n\n\u2022 They know it is hard work, but it is worth it.\n\n\u2022 They are passionate about the causes for which they are raising money.\n\n\u2022 They come not as beggars, but as individuals of fering others opportunities to invest\nin the future of their communities.\n\n\u2022 They are the catalyst for converting citizens to donor-investors in the organizations\nwhose values they share.\n\npreface xiii\n\nfm.qxd (i-xx)  3/3/05  3:04 PM  Page xiii\n\n\n\n\u2022 They f ind the process to be satisfying and gratifying.\n\n\u2022 They see it as a way of involving people known and unknown to them in organi-\nzations that are making a dif ference in their communities.\n\nFor those who have made the attitudinal breakthrough, an invitation to provide or ask\nfor funds for an organization is an invitation to invest or ask others to invest. Each act of\ngiving and asking is an honor, a privilege, and a trust. We can measure the impact of\ngifts by the results the organization achieves.\n\nI have watched as board members, other volunteers, staf f members, and the curious\nwho are not yet involved with philanthropy realize that asking for money is an invita-\ntion to invest. I have heard their stories of the transforming nature of both asking and\ngiving, and I have listened as they relate their increased stakeholder role. I have seen\nwhat happens to attitudes about fundraising when people realize that the investment\ngoes beyond the organization: that an investment made in a not-for-prof it organization\nis an investment in the community. And I have seen donors transformed through their\ninvestments and their sense of involvement and belonging.\n\nThese are powerful realizations.We have been helped in the last f ive or more years by\nan increased awareness in the media of our power and impact. No longer relegated to\npage 16 of local and national newspapers and magazines (or to the local or social sec-\ntion), news of philanthropic investments is front page. Magazines understand us now as\na vital social force. We can hope that the old days of disparaging and ignorant coverage\nof our sector are gone. When I ref lect on the way things were, I remember how one of\nthe high-circulation magazines wrote about major university capital campaigns that were\nunder way a decade ago. The article was titled \u201cAmerica\u2019s Top Universities Go Begging\nin Style.\u201d I hope we have gone beyond that image. We do not come from weakness. We\nhave no need to beg. We come from the strength of our visible impact, convictions, and\nvalues. The perception of our sector is changing, and with it the demands for account-\nability and disclosure are rising. We are meeting those demands, but still have a distance\nto go. We need to promote ourselves more vigorously as the \u201cpublic benef it sector\u201d and\nas public benef it organizations\u2014leaving the label of \u201ccharity\u201d to the more appropriate\ndescription of the purpose for which we have been created and the reasons that people\ngive (charitable intent, charitable purpose). \u201cCharity\u201d connotes to far too many people\norganizations that are needy. We are not needy: we meet needs. Even \u201cnonprof it\u201d has its\ndrawbacks\u2014what other sector of the economy describes itself by what it is not? (Peter\nHero, CEO, Community Foundation Silicon Valley)\n\nAs we go ever more deliberately beyond fundraising into systemic development prac-\ntices that focus on the donor, the community, social investment, and innovation, we will\nensure that the new perception of our sector holds.\n\nA Book of Tested Ideas\n\nIn 1997, with the f irst edition, I drew on my experience for the observations, strategies,\nand tips in this book. As I reviewed them in 2005, the vast majority remained true.\n\nxiv preface\n\nfm.qxd (i-xx)  3/3/05  3:04 PM  Page xiv\n\n\n\nClients and audiences change, the marketplace has def initely changed, donors are vastly\ndif ferent, and yet the core principles set forth in this book have lasted. Perhaps it was\nahead of its time.\n\nMy passions about the not-for-prof it sector are many. These passions include ethics,\nvalues, creativity, innovation, professionalism, board participation, pride in the sector,\npartnerships at all levels of an organization and in the community, and a keen sense of\nmission and vision. My passions are characterized by an absence of cynicism and an abun-\ndance of enthusiasm. Recently a colleague asked me if I am always \u201cso optimistic.\u201d My\nanswer was yes. I remain optimistic about the power and potential of philanthropy and\nthe great gains we are making in America and around the globe.The late John W. Gardner,\nboth mentor and friend to me, instructed us that as leaders we must of fer hope.That has\nalways been my goal.\n\nA Book for Volunteers and Staff \nThroughout the World\n\nThis book is for both paid and unpaid leaders and servants of the not-for-prof it sector\nthroughout the world. Its principles are universal. Many philanthropic practices and\nstrategies, long a part of the American tradition, have been implemented with vision\nand success in countries throughout the world. Cross-cultural adaptations will of course\nbe made by those in other countries implementing American ideas\u2014even by our close\nneighbors and colleagues in Latin America and Canada\u2014but the kernel of each strategy\nis sound.\n\nAs my work has expanded globally in recent years, so has my perspective and under-\nstanding of both common and divergent practices.\n\nCertain ideas and issues have distilled with force and clarity. Although the primary\nfocus of the sector will always be on ways to generate more revenue, it is a growing reality\nthat fundraising is not enough. Experienced organizations know this is so. In practice,\nunfortunately, they too often ignore this crucial truth. They do not take the time to do\nthe kind of relationship building that is indispensable for long-term development. Even\nif they cultivate their prospects well\u2014building relationships as a prelude to asking for\nthe gift\u2014they often fail repeatedly at donor stewardship. In a recent survey done to\nassess factors that would lure lapsed members back to public television, one woman\nresponded:\u201cThey would have to show me that they know me.\u201d\n\nStewardship is not just diligent monitoring of the way in which a person\u2019s gift is\ninvested or used. Stewardship is the process of involving and appreciating donor-investors\nand bringing them into a deeper relationship with the organization after the gift is\nmade. Stewardship is the most critical development practice. It encourages long-term\ninvestment in our sector. The importance of stewardship threads its way through this\nbook, and there is an entire chapter dedicated to it as well.\n\nWith business and government unable, unwilling, or ill-equipped to do what we do,\nwe play an increasingly vital role. In a healthy society, nonprof its must provide both\n\npreface xv\n\nfm.qxd (i-xx)  3/3/05  3:04 PM  Page xv\n\n\n\ninitiative and response. We need only ref lect on the outpouring of sympathy and sup-\nport following the 9/11 terrorist attack in the United States and the Tsunami that dev-\nastated South Asian and African communities on the Indian Ocean in December, 2004,\nto see the capacity of people to care. Organizations quickly positioned themselves to\nmeet the desperate human needs of these communities and people responded.\n\nGoing forward into the twenty-f irst century, the philanthropic sector has an oppor-\ntunity to build stronger communities through boldness, innovation, and new models for\naction that are based on results, not needs; investment opportunities, not institutional\nf inancial urgency. As observer, counselor, teacher, constructive critic, and conf idante, I\nhave been privileged beyond expression to work with staf f and volunteer leaders who\nare truly making a dif ference in the health and stability of our society. This book is for\nyou, and for all those who wish to bring innovation and investment to their communities.\n\nKAY SPRINKEL GRACE\n\nMarch 2005\n\nxvi preface\n\nfm.qxd (i-xx)  3/3/05  3:04 PM  Page xvi\n\n\n\nxvii\n\nIntroduction to the Second Edition\n\nThe changes that have occurred in philanthropy since I began writing Beyond Fund-\nraising in 1995 and since it was published in 1997 are substantial. We have seen the Amer-\nican economic bubble swell and burst and begin to grow again.With the unprecedented\ngrowth in wealth came an extraordinary and generation-spanning awareness of the power\nof philanthropic investment.\n\nCover stories during 1999\u20132001 in Business Week, Forbes, Success, Fortune and com-\nprehensive articles in publications as far-reaching as The New York Times and The Econo-\nmist focused on the awakening of widespread interest in ways for individual social\ninvestors, through philanthropic gifts, to help meet the needs of their communities. The\n\u201cgolden age\u201d of philanthropy came upon us: Vast wealth was created, and the \u201cnew phi-\nlanthropists\u201d (whether in their 20s or their 70s) recognized the satisfying return of this\nnew kind of investment. But that satisfaction was based on new demands on the sector.\nAccountability and transparency became the requirement for philanthropic investment,\nand public benef it corporations (nonprof its) not only began providing more information\nbut began offering more opportunities for donor involvement in their organizations.\n\nAstride this fast-paced movement toward greater and deeper investment, which was\ninf luenced in tempo and leadership by young entrepreneurs impatient to change the\nworld, our sector rode a roller coaster. Eager for the investment, some organizations\nagreed to conditions that placed undue strain on their management and boards, and\noften led to disappointed investors. \u201cVenture philanthropy\u201d became a hotly debated\ntopic, and standards for performance by organizations in our sector were scrutinized.\n\nParallel with these changes in the United States, our active exportation of philan-\nthropy to far-f lung corners of the world f lourished. Many of our great social entrepre-\nneurs and investors\u2014Bill and Melinda Gates, George Soros\u2014saw with keen vision that\nglobalization was not just about economics. It was about our interconnectedness with\npeople and our common quest to improve education, eradicate poverty, and eliminate\nboth chronic and catastrophic diseases. Our greatest social export, philanthropy, found\nnew markets\u2014driven by new freedom in eastern Europe, a rising epidemic of AIDS in\n\nfm.qxd (i-xx)  3/3/05  3:04 PM  Page xvii\n\n\n\nxviii introduction\n\nAfrica, a persistent need for social services and change in western Europe and Asia, and\na growing recognition in all parts of the world that governments were never again going\nto fund community organizations at the level many countries had experienced in pre-\nvious centuries.\n\nAs social investors demanded more oversight of their investment and wanted more\ncontrol over their wealth while considering to what philanthropic purpose it would be\nput, another change occurred. Community foundations in the United States burgeoned,\nswelled by donor-advised funds and supporting organizations that provided investors\nwith advice from experienced philanthropic managers while of fering them the desired\ncontrol over their money and their investments. This movement, too, resonated with\nresourceful people outside the United States and the community foundation movement\ntook f ire.WINGS (Worldwide Initiatives for Grantmaker Support), in its May 2004 \u201c2004\nCommunity Foundation Global Status Report,\u201d highlighted these developments among\nothers:\n\n\u2022 42 countries have community foundations, up from 36 in 2003, and 8 more coun-\ntries are seriously considering forming foundations.\n\n\u2022 1,120 community foundations exist worldwide with another 142 in active formation.\n\n\u2022 37.5 percent of these exist outside the United States, up from 34 percent in 2003;\nCanada and the United States together represent 47 percent of the foundations,\ndown from 52 percent in 2003.\n\n\u2022 Between 1999 and 2004, the number of community foundations outside North\nAmerica grew by 176 percent.\n\n\u2022 The f irst ever global meeting of community foundation practitioners from around\nthe world gathered at the Community Foundation Symposium in Berlin in Decem-\nber 2004\u2014 a \u201crecognition of how far the global movement has progressed in just\nten years.\u201d\n\nThe truly remarkable aspect of all of this is that the core philanthropic interest, curiosity,\nand energy of the late twentieth and early twenty-f irst centuries persists in spite of the\nfact that we have, since September 11, 2001, been coming to grips with enormous\nchanges in our economy, our sense of personal safety, and the overall stability of the\nworld.The War on Terrorism will most likely be the long war that politicians and scholars\npredict, and no country is immune. From the United States to Indonesia to Spain to parts\nof the former Soviet Union, the threat of terrorism spawns fear and distracts people from\nthe dreams and vision they once had.\n\nThe inf luence on philanthropy of the focus on global safety has been visible in meas-\nurable ways (giving was down in the United States in 2002 as philanthropy did not\nrespond with its usual safety net to the economic downturn and loss of public funding)\nand in the most subtle ways (people feel a sense of \u201cpsychic poverty\u201d that causes even\nthose who maintained or have now restored their wealth to feel less inclined to give it\naway). In the hierarchy of human needs that Abraham Maslow listed so many decades\nago, we slipped down from the lofty perch of focusing on self-actualization and began\n\nfm.qxd (i-xx)  3/3/05  3:04 PM  Page xviii\n\n\n\nintroduction xix\n\nto worry about food, shelter, and other basic needs as the economy continued to remain\nvolatile even late into 2004. Philanthropy is recovering, and we need only ref lect on the\noverwhelming response from individuals around the world to the plight of those who\nendured and survived the Indian Ocean Tsunami of December 2004 to see that once\nagain, when confronted with extreme human tragedy, people give as much as they can\nto help others.\n\nSo what is philanthropy\u2019s role today? And how does this book\u2014whose ideas seem\nremarkably resilient even 10 years later\u2014become your travel guide for the uncertain\nand sure to be surprising road ahead?\n\nPhilanthropy\u2019s role today is, for me, more important than ever. When kept free of pol-\nitics and based on a mission-secured vision of meeting community needs and enhancing\nthe quality of life, what greater safety line can we grasp in these uncertain times? Com-\nmunity problems do not recede in times of international crisis, they grow. And while our\nsense of helplessness or powerlessness may rise during times of threats to health, security,\nor social conditions, what better way to restore our sense of being able to have an impact\nthan by investing in organizations that are making a dif ference in lives nearby or those far\naway? And there is no more ef fective way to bridge both of these worlds: last year for\nChristmas I \u201cgave\u201d my grandchildren goats, chickens, and rabbits through Heifer Interna-\ntional, animals that are now providing food and industry for families in Asia. Even the\nsmallest children in the family understood the message of philanthropic outreach.\n\nBeyond Fundraising has sold more than 12,000 copies in its f irst edition and is still\nselling well. This new edition incorporates the new context for philanthropy, but the\nsolid principles that have led to this book\u2019s success have not been altered.The values basis\nfor philanthropy is still the only basis; mission is still a ref lection of why an organization\nexists, not just what it does; the importance of regarding donors as donor-investors (or\njust as investors) has grown; vision is still the star to hitch your wagon to; and the basic\nstrategies for annual and capital fundraising are little altered. There is one entirely new\nchapter, the two chapters on planning in the f irst edition have been combined into one,\nand the remainder have been revised, edited, and updated.\n\nIn the near decade since I began the f irst writing of this book, my insights and career\nhave changed along with the philanthropic environment. The variety of clients has not\nchanged (arts and culture, public broadcasting, secondary and higher education, health\nand human services, environment, and religion), but I now spend more time speaking\nand writing. Annual exposure to hundreds and hundreds of people who work or volun-\nteer in philanthropy has spiked my passion for what our sector accomplishes. Increased\nwork with boards of directors has increased my respect for the changes we may have to\nmake in governance policies and procedures to accelerate access by investors. My work\nwith public broadcasting, now an all-consuming role that will continue for the next sev-\neral years, is a microcosm of each of our communities here in the United States, inte-\ngrating arts, education, health, public af fairs, and other programming with community\npartnerships that are based on the reality that broadcasting is not what public broadcast-\nings does, it is how it does what it does. It has provided me a window into all of your\nworlds, and the view is one of potential realized and potential that remains. My work\n\nfm.qxd (i-xx)  3/3/05  3:04 PM  Page xix\n\n\n\ninternationally has likewise given me a new f ilter\u2014to see the life cycle of philanthropy\nref lected in its entirety in a classroom at the International Fundraising Congress is a rare\ngift\u2014and I become less a teacher than a facilitator; less a pedant than a midwife. When\nI hear how an African gentlemen who administers a trust has the responsibility to spend\n$1 million a year on children orphaned by AIDS\u2014and he then tells me there are 1 mil-\nlion children in his country already orphaned\u2014I am humbled by the wisdom he must\nuse to make his decisions. And when I see how philanthropy is soaring in Australia and\nNew Zealand, I am thrilled by the changes I have seen since I f irst went there 11 years\nago to speak at a fundraising conference.\n\nWe work and volunteer in a remarkable sector. Our capacity to build long-term rela-\ntionships will be critical to its further impact. These relationships must be based on an\nunderstanding between organizations and their donor-investors of their mutual respon-\nsibilities. It needs to be a relationship based on partnership, respect, and vision.\n\nThis book is about building those relationships. It is about strengthening the platform\nfrom which you operate so that you can truly soar. Filled with concrete examples and\ntips, it is also abundantly stocked with philosophical and strategic morsels that will sat-\nisfy your appetite for something more meaningful than what is in your in-box\u2014but\nsomething that will help you deal better with the pile of daily duties.\n\nYour role is great and important. Our sector represents hope for the future.\n\nxx introduction\n\nfm.qxd (i-xx)  3/3/05  3:04 PM  Page xx\n\n\n\nPhilanthropic behavior is motivated by values. Board member commitment to serve\nand ask, volunteer enthusiasm, and a donor-investor\u2019s sense of satisfaction in giving are\nbased on an implicit search for ways to act on their values. Matching volunteer, funder,\nand institutional values is a critical practice of successful nonprof it organizations.\n\nPhilanthropy Defined\n\nHistorically, philanthropy was \u201clove of mankind\u201d or (later) \u201clove of humankind.\u201d Its\nmanifestation, particularly in the United States where philanthropy has been practiced\nconsistently since the earliest years of its founding, has included voluntary of ferings of\ntime, money, and goods to meet the needs of communities. The popular perception of\nphilanthropy that grew during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries focused on major\nf inancial support of wealthy individuals like Andrew Carnegie, John D. Rockefeller, and\nin more recent times, David and Lucile Packard, and Bill and Melinda Gates. Recogniz-\ning that philanthropy is historically and in practice much more than giving money, a\nnewer def inition of philanthropy was developed decades ago by Robert Payton in his\nbook Philanthropy:Voluntary Action for the Public Good (1988): all voluntary action for the\npublic good. Based in values, voluntary action includes giving, asking, joining, and serving.\n\nWe know by observation and experience that people do not engage in philanthropic\nactivities on behalf of organizations1 whose values they do not share.The match between\nthe values of our organizations and the values of our constituencies predicts the level and\nintensity of the response a donor or volunteer will have to a cause.\n\nTo be innovative and attract long-term donor investment, organizations in the non-\nprof it sector must def ine and apply their values. They should organize their internal\nsystems, marketing and communications programs, and community outreach to maximize\nthe understanding of, response to, and impact of those values. Only then can organizations\n\nValues: The Context for Philanthropy,\nDevelopment, and Fundraising\n\n1\n\n1\nchapter\n\nc01.qxd (001-016)  3/3/05  3:02 PM  Page 1\n\n\n\nattract supporters for the right reasons and engage them in a lasting and mutually satis-\nfying relationship.\n\nThe Role of Values in the Nonprofit Sector\n\nComplex and passionate values are often present at the creation of nonprof it organizations.\nWishing to act meaningfully on those values, people create and help sustain organizations\nthat meet a variety of community needs. They do this through their philanthropic gifts\nof time and money.\n\n\u2022 Parents whose son or daughter dies of a drug overdose channel their grief into con-\nstructive options for other young people by creating a counseling program at the\nlocal high school.\n\n\u2022 Because she values independent living and the dignity deserved by all individuals,\nthe grandmother of a developmentally disabled young adult helps create a center for\nher grandchild and for others with similar disabilities.\n\n\u2022 The American Library in Paris is founded by the father of an American poet-sol-\ndier killed in World War I.\n\n\u2022 The families of leukemia patients in Queensland,Australia, help create an apartment\nbuilding where they can stay while loved ones receive hospital treatment.\n\nOther motivations may be less personal but are no less value-driven.\n\n\u2022 In the United States, the movement to keep local and regional symphonies strong and\naccessible is based in values: Community leaders realize that live music performances\nenhance the attractiveness of their communities, that children and adults need oppor-\ntunities to appreciate and learn about music, and that local musicians need to play\ntogether as an orchestra.\n\n\u2022 Public school districts in California and other parts of the United States, constrained\nby cuts in tax revenues, create private foundations to raise money to support jeop-\nardized school programs. They are the invention of parents motivated by values of\nquality and opportunity in education.\n\n\u2022 In Slovenia, citizens ensure the creation of a children\u2019s services agency to replace vital\nhealthcare programs previously provided by government.\n\n\u2022 In countless public broadcasting stations across America, staf f and volunteers wish-\ning to sustain the independent and local media voice in their communities create and\nimplement new ways for their members to invest at higher levels in support of pro-\ngrams that advance classroom education, children\u2019s programming, arts and culture,\ncivil discourse, lifelong learning, and other basic needs of their communities.\n\nGlobal philanthropy is growing exponentially.Throughout the world, communities are\nresponding to changes in traditional sources of services and revenue by creating and sus-\ntaining support for museums, schools, social and human service agencies, and other vital\n\n2 beyond fundraising\n\nc01.qxd (001-016)  3/3/05  3:02 PM  Page 2\n\n\n\ninstitutions. Motivated by their own values and the values of their communities, leaders\nare taking on new roles as community builders.\n\nWhile inspired by America\u2019s globally unique nonprof it leadership, international phil-\nanthropic organizations are developing their own unique character, ref lecting the values\nand needs of the communities they serve. The growth of the ResourceAlliance, a global\nphilanthropic organization headquartered in the United Kingdom that provides confer-\nences and training to professionals throughout the world, is a stunning sign of this growth.\nFrom a single, modestly attended annual International Fundraising Congress held 25 years\nago in The Netherlands, the organization has grown to sponsor not only its annual con-\nference with capacity attendance but regular regional conferences throughout the world\n(Africa, South Asia, Latin America) that are dedicated to increasing the capacity of orga-\nnizations in these countries to meet pressing community needs through appropriate and\neffective philanthropy.The rapid spread of philanthropy is an unexpected benef it of glob-\nalization, accelerating needed change by drawing on resources and ideas that are readily\nshared among caring people and organizations.\n\nDeveloping a Values-Based Approach\n\nSystems and structures that successfully attract volunteers and funding rely on the iden-\ntif ication of common values. These values become the foundation of all outreach and\noperations. Board members, other volunteers, and staf f know intuitively why they are\ncommitted to an organization or to the voluntary sector, but most have not articulated\nthe values that attract them. Nonprof it leaders, who may be stymied in their ability to\nconvey a fresh or convincing message asking for community support, benef it from revis-\niting the core values of their organizations as a f irst step in addressing their mission and\nmarketing. The results of such an exercise are heartening. Renewed motivation is often\nimmediate, and there is reaf f irmation of founding or sustaining principles.They take the\nf irst step toward values-directed outreach to the community that can result in revitalized\nsupport. One venerable organization, preparing for a campaign to coincide with its 150th\nanniversary, engaged board and senior staf f in a \u201cdeep-dive\u201d session that identif ied their\ncore values.Two outcomes were important: (1) the sense of unity that came from the real-\nization of the extent of their shared values and (2) the ease with which these identif ied\nvalues formed the basis for an entirely new marketing program.\n\nWhether an organization is long-established and looking for a current perspective or\nnew and looking for a solid basis on which to construct its outreach, the identif ication\nof values is a signif icant f irst step.\n\nIdentifying Values\n\nValues orientation is outward. It requires organizations to replace their windows with\nmirrors and identify those aspects of their beliefs and practices that will link with the\nneeds of the community and the values of their existing and potential constituencies. In\n\nchapter 1 values 3\n\nc01.qxd (001-016)  3/3/05  3:02 PM  Page 3\n\n\n\norganizations that are evolving from a focus on the needs they have to an emphasis on\nthe needs they are meeting, this can be a dif f icult step. Used to conducting community\noutreach and fundraising based on internal f inancial needs, they require some coaching\nto transcend old habits and focus on the core values that can attract and retain like-\nminded people.\n\nValues vary among organizations and donors. Here are some examples of core values\nexpressed by staf f and volunteers in organizations during sessions conducted to discuss\nthe values that motivate people to give to and serve their organizations:\n\n\u2022 A YMCA: youth, leadership, families, community, health\n\n\u2022 An arts education organization: creativity, expression, learning, opportunity, family\ninvolvement\n\n\u2022 A children\u2019s services organization: safety, health, care, concern, families, healing,\nopportunities\n\n\u2022 A medical center: healing, continuum of care, excellence, compassion\n\nSome will argue that the values which drive some people to support highly visible arts,\ncultural, and educational organizations are self-serving: recognition, opportunity to mingle\nwith the rich and famous, or prestige. These motivations should be viewed without crit-\nicism and as opportunities for exploration of other values. A person\u2019s motivation for giving\nan annual or capital gift, as long as it is within the ethical and values framework of the\nrecipient organization, should be the starting point of a relationship. Over time, the ini-\ntial WIIFM (What\u2019s in it for me?) motivation can be converted to a desire to work together\nwith an organization to make a difference in an area of mutually perceived importance.\n\nThe identif ication and nurturing of the values that people bring to their initial inter-\naction with an organization are the f irst steps toward going beyond fundraising.\n\nOrganizations that position themselves as facilitators rather than judges create oppor-\ntunities that bring people into a larger understanding of the impact of their involvement.\nMany initial gifts, given in response to peer pressure during an annual or capital campaign,\ncan, with patience and the application of good listening skills, be not only renewed but\ngrown when the donor\u2019s values are uncovered and matched with the values of the orga-\nnization. While some gifts should not be accepted, and your organization should have\npolicies that indicate sources or purposes that are inappropriate, most volunteers and pro-\nfessionals are wise enough to know when donor motivation is inconsistent with the mis-\nsion of the organization and could lead to a compromise of the institution\u2019s values. Such\ninstances are quite rare, and these gifts are almost always rejected. Many years ago,Yale\nUniversity returned a $20 million gift to the donors. The gift had come with a string\nattached:The donors wished to inf luence the curriculum in the academic area for which\nthe gift was designated. Yale\u2019s commitment to the integrity of its curriculum develop-\nment process prevailed. In another instance, an environmental organization rejected the\noffer of a gift from a corporation whose purpose was counter-value to the mission of the\nnonprof it.\n\n4 beyond fundraising\n\nc01.qxd (001-016)  3/3/05  3:02 PM  Page 4\n\n\n\nexhibit 1.1 interrel ationship of \nvalues-based phil anthropy,\nde velopment,  and fundr aising\n\nchapter 1 values 5\n\nPhilanthropy\n\nBased in values\n\nDevelopment\n\nUncovers shared values\n\nFundraising\n\nProvides people \nopportunities to\n\nact on their values\n\nA Model of Values-Based Philanthropy,\nDevelopment, and Fundraising\n\nMastery of the interrelationship of values-based philanthropy, development, and fundrais-\ning is a critical achievement for organizations seeking innovative and powerful ways to\nposition themselves in their communities. Exhibit 1.1 shows how these three functions\noperate as one seamless context for donor development. The integration of these func-\ntions is the primary catalyst for going beyond fundraising.\n\nUnderstanding the Model\n\nThe largest element of this model is philanthropy, as redef ined by Payton and others. It\nis the context in which development and fundraising must be set.\n\nMost nonprof it volunteer and staf f leaders, introduced to the bigger idea that philan-\nthropy is all voluntary action for the public good, not just gift-gathering, immediately\ngrasp its role as a larger and more exciting framework in which to plan and set priori-\nties. The challenge to old ways of thinking comes even more forcefully in understand-\ning the dif ference between development and fundraising. In a survey administered as part\nof a video teaching guide by the BoardSource (formerly the National Center for Nonprofit\n\nc01.qxd (001-016)  3/3/05  3:02 PM  Page 5\n\n\n\nBoards), the majority of participants indicated that \u201cdevelopment\u201d was just a \u201cnicer way\u201d\nof saying fundraising. This model illustrates why that is not true.\n\nThis three-part model distinguishes between development and fundraising and places\nthese functions as embedded in philanthropy. It separates the process of development\nfrom the activities of fundraising and assigns each a dif ferent function within the values-\nframed structure.\n\nThe model has three elements: philanthropy, development, and fundraising.\n\nPhilanthropy: Based in Values\n\nPhilanthropy is the largest part of the model. It is based on the belief that philanthropy\nis directed by values. The research of Payton and others has verif ied this conclusion. We\ndo not give to, ask for, join, or serve those organizations whose values are inconsistent\nwith our own. At the most altruistic, this motivation draws people into a rewarding\ninvolvement with organizations that are advancing and strengthening basic community\nand individual values. At the other end of the continuum, there will be those whose ini-\ntial motivation is WIIFM (What\u2019s in it for me?). These initial motivations (recognition,\nenhanced community position), as discussed previously, can be grown over time into a\ndeeper understanding of mutual benef its for donor and organization.\n\nBecause core values are broad (e.g., dignity, independence, excellence, compassion,\nquality of life), they permit access to organizations by a wide range of donors with dif fer-\ning needs and perceptions. Messages can encompass all or one of these values. Values also\ncross boundaries from one organization to another. Those who value families or health\nor safety will f ind several organizations in a community in whose work they can invest.\nThis reduces the sense of competition among organizations and focuses instead on the\nimportance of fulf illing a values-centered community mission that may be acted on by\nseveral institutions.\n\nTwo Institutions: Common Mission, Common Values\nIn one community, two organizations working with women and their children who had\nexperienced domestic violence combined their ef forts in one community campaign. An\nemergency shelter and a transition housing/job training program conducted a joint fund-\nraising campaign one year under the mutual banner of \u201cbreaking the cycle of violence.\u201d\nAn advertising agency provided high-quality pro bono print and electronic public serv-\nice promotional materials, and a well-respected county supervisor was the keynoter at the\ncampaign kickoff.The two organizations shared more than $75,000 in contributions from\nthe joint campaign. Each organization also conducted its own fundraising activities that\nyear, separate from the joint campaign but ref lecting the common mission. Community\nawareness of the issue of domestic violence was heightened by the joint campaign, and\nresponse to the individual agency campaigns ref lected this as well. The public service\nannouncements were timeless in their production and appeal, and still are seen occasionally\non the local television station.The two organizations attracted new donors who identif ied\nwith their shared values and renewed existing donors who saw with fresh clarity the\nimportance of breaking the cycle of violence.\n\n6 beyond fundraising\n\nc01.qxd (001-016)  3/3/05  3:02 PM  Page 6\n\n\n\nTranslating Philanthropy: In Conveying Values, the Mission Is the Message\nThe invitation to participate as a donor-investor or volunteer in values-based philan-\nthropy is best of fered through a mission statement that ref lects those values. Many non-\nprof it organizations have succumbed to the pressure of people who are uncomfortable\nwith statements that incorporate values or emotions and have created mission statements\nthat are \u201ccorporate,\u201d describing what the organization does, rather than why.\n\nTo embark on successful values-based philanthropy, development, and fundraising, it is\nvery important to have a mission statement that states why the organization exists. It may\nalso say what the organization does, but the function (what) should be secondary to the\npurpose (why). One major donor to a midwestern public broadcasting licensee parsed a\nmodel mission statement and observed that a good one combines the \u201cusers\u2019 emotions\nwith the station\u2019s (or organization\u2019s) functionality.\u201d An astute observation with applica-\ntion far beyond public broadcasting.\n\nWhat Mission Statements Should Say and Do\nNonprof it organizations exist to fulf ill community needs. People do not give time and\nmoney to organizations because organizations have needs; they give because organizations\nmeet needs. In that spirit, we know that a gift to an organization is really a gift through the\norganization: It is an investment in the community. These are the two key premises for\ngoing beyond fundraising.\n\nMission statements that describe only the function of an organization need to frame that\nfunction with the purpose: Why does an organization exist? What need is being met?\nAlthough some values are present in a statement of what an organization does, the core\nvalues that will ignite interest are more boldly expressed in a statement of why the orga-\nnization exists. The Fundraising School, a program of Indiana University\u2019s Center on\nPhilanthropy, has generated the seminal work in values-based mission statements. Its basic\ncourse materials include numerous examples of statements that answer the question \u201cWhy\ndo you exist?\u201d\n\nTwo Examples of Values-Based Mission Statements\nOver the years, certain organizations have framed and used mission statements that are\npowerful invitations to invest. Vector Health Programs of Eureka, California, which spe-\ncializes in procedures for repairing severe injuries to hands, developed one nearly 15 years\nago that, although no longer in use, remains a stunning model. Its executive director at\nthat time, Karen Angel, prepared the statement as part of a workshop exercise. Her initial\nmission statement, which was a description of Vector\u2019s services, was challenged as not\nanswering the \u201cwhy\u201d question and lacking an expression of core values. In response to\nthe question \u201cWhy do you exist?\u201d she wrote:\n\nNext to the human face, hands are our most expressive feature. We talk with them. We work\nwith them.We play with them.We comfort and love with them. An injury to the hand af fects\npeople personally and professionally. At Vector Health Programs, we give people back the use\nof their hands.\n\nchapter 1 values 7\n\nc01.qxd (001-016)  3/3/05  3:02 PM  Page 7\n\n\n\nThe statement went on to describe how Vector restores the use of people\u2019s hands. The\nboard chair, hearing this statement the f irst time, was moved to tears. She said she had\nnot realized, until then, just why she was involved.The mission statement had intersected\nwith, and revealed, her values of full participation in life, love, work, and play.\n\nIn another example,Yale University School of Medicine positioned this values-based\nmission statement as the lead to its case materials for a capital campaign conducted nearly\nthree decades ago, when the scientif ic world was in the beginning of the explosion of\nknowledge about genetics. Like Vector\u2019s mission statement, time has not tarnished the\nluster of this strong example of an excellent mission statement:\n\nWe are in the midst of one of the most profound intellectual revolutions of all time, the rev-\nolution in the biological sciences. Its implications for understanding life processes and for com-\nbating disease are boundless.Yale is in the forefront of this revolution.\n\nSuccinct and potent, this brief statement ref lects values of excellence, innovation, and\ninvolvement, and invites those who share those values to participate in the campaign.\n\nA recent example (October 2004) comes from public broadcasting.WVIA in Pittston,\nPennsylvania (western Pennsylvania) has drafted this new mission expression:\n\nPeople change and lives improve when powerful ideas confront us. WVIA is a regional cata-\nlyst, convener and educator, using media, partnership, ideas and programs to advance the best\nattributes of an enlightened society.\n\nGetting Comfortable with Expressing Values\nIt is not enough to have values.To attract those who share them, values must be expressed.\nIf organizations are reluctant to present a values-based mission statement to an increas-\ningly critical and pragmatic public, they still should go through the exercise of identify-\ning their core values and incorporating them into a written expression. The statement\nthey develop may be for internal use only, but its presence will serve to inspire and moti-\nvate those who must engage others in institutional advancement.\n\nOrganizational reluctance to create and publish a values-based mission statement is\npuzzling. A look at most American and international advertising shows how emotions and\nvalues are used for commercial gain. Makers of automobiles, soft drinks, food products,\ncleaning goods, ice cream, insurance, health plans, and other consumer goods are not at\nall reluctant to use values language and benef its in their marketing. A nonprof it\u2019s mission\nstatement is not an advertisement, but it is used to attract potential donors and volunteers\nin the way an advertisement is used to convince the consumer to purchase a product or\nservice. As ref lected in the three mission statements just quoted, there is room for modest\nexpression of emotion in nonprof it mission statements. This emotion is anchored by\nvalues and is never excessive or of fensive. Most nonprof it organizations have an emo-\ntional basis to their origin and impact: To deny this in a mission statement or other mate-\nrials seems oddly contradictory to purpose.\n\nAn advertising executive of fered himself as a constructive critic of his alma mater\u2019s\nseries of fundraising mailings. He cited an overintellectualism that did not ignite any\n\n8 beyond fundraising\n\nc01.qxd (001-016)  3/3/05  3:02 PM  Page 8\n\n\n\nmemories or emotions for him. He admonished the university\u2019s development staf f to\nevoke the images that stirred nostalgia, a key value among alumni: the smell of a campus\ngrove after a rain, the sound of the stadium at a football game\u2019s halftime, the taste of\ncof fee hastily drunk between classes and with friends. His ideas were incorporated into\nthe next year\u2019s mailings, with positive results.\n\nCreating a Values-Based Mission Statement\nCreating a values-based mission statement is not easy, but it is important to do. The\nembodiment of values in a mission statement can inspire other materials including mail-\nings and proposals. It can be a talking point when recruiting volunteers and the core of\nspeeches and presentations. A mission statement cannot be written by a committee, but\nit will benef it from an initial idea-generating session that involves key constituents. Iden-\ntifying core values is the f irst step.\n\nIn the previously mentioned session at the 150-year-old institution, each person wrote\ndown what he or she believed to be the three core values of the organization.The facili-\ntator then asked each person to state one value from their list. After the f irst round,\nparticipants were asked to repeat the process, stating any values on their lists that were \nnot yet on the master list. Duplications arose by the second round, which is why it is\nimportant to request just one value from each person at the outset. A side benef it of\nthis process is participant awareness of the degree to which they recognize and share the\norganization\u2019s values.\n\nOrganizations will f ind this exercise very helpful in focusing board and staff on common\nvalues. Once these values have been identif ied, the same participants are asked to com-\nplete this sentence:\u201c(Our organization) exists because. . . .\u201dThey should be coached that\nthe statements are not to be written using the inf initive form of the verb (to inform,\nto educate, etc.), but rather as a statement incorporating the values just identif ied and\nexpressing the reasons why the organization exists. This instruction was the inspiration\nfor the mission statement about hands from Vector Health Programs. Examples help get\npeople started on this new approach to mission statement creation.\n\nThese \u201cwhy\u201d expressions, and the lists of core values, provide the raw material for shap-\ning the f irst draft of a mission statement. Assign the writing task to an individual with\nwriting skills and a command of institutional history and priorities. Establish agreements\nregarding the review process and the extent to which the statement will be edited before\nthe writing begins. Many f ine, nimble, evocative, and inspiring statements turn into\nclumsy, inclusive, meaningless, and rambling paragraphs because too many people are\ngiven opportunities to whittle and alter the f irst or subsequent drafts. In one organiza-\ntion, a whole board meeting was devoted to the subtle yet substantial dif ference between\n\u201csocial injustice\u201d and \u201csocial injustices\u201d as contained in the draft mission statement. The\ngroup was divided irreconcilably over the nuance of these phrases, and the mission writing\nprocess was blocked.\n\nOnce a draft has been approved internally, organizations can benef it from circulating\nthe statement to a select group of donor-investors.This group may include former board\n\nchapter 1 values 9\n\nc01.qxd (001-016)  3/3/05  3:02 PM  Page 9\n\n\n\nmembers, major donors, and others who will respond to and appreciate being included\nin this \u201cinsider\u201d communication. One organization, testing concepts derived from its mis-\nsion for use in a capital campaign, received valuable feedback that led it to shape the cam-\npaign materials in a slightly dif ferent way. The modif ication created a more broadly\nappealing message and resulted in participation by a constituency that otherwise might\nhave not been involved.\n\nAccepting and Using Values-Based Mission Statements\nSome mission statements, ref lecting organizational values and the need the organization\nis meeting, may never receive endorsement by boards or staf f. Instead, leaders may approve\nand publish a more expository statement of the organization\u2019s functions. Although almost\nalways uninspiring, these statements satisfy the need people have within and outside an\norganization for a mission statement that more closely matches those written for corpo-\nrations or law f irms. It is still prudent, however, to have an expression of the institution\u2019s\nvalues on hand.\n\nSometimes a values-based mission statement will be adopted later or integrated into\nmaterials not as a mission statement, but as a framework for expressing the organization\u2019s\npurpose. On numerous occasions, organizations have turned to values-driven expressions\nof their mission when making tough decisions about their future. An organization that\noperated summer camps for a large religious organization found itself turning toward a\nstatement of values and purpose at a decisive moment in its history. The development\ndirector had participated in a workshop in which he was asked to create a mission state-\nment. On his return to his organization, the statement was received negatively.The direc-\ntor kept what he had written, feeling there might be use for it some day. There was. A\nyear later, at a board-staf f retreat, the participants were at loggerheads about the direc-\ntion in which the organization should be heading. Hours of debate created acrimony and\ndissent. A proposed action was outside the mission according to some; to others, it was\nthe next logical step. The development director saw this as the moment to reintroduce\nhis values-based mission statement to the group.When he f inished reading his statement,\nthere was no longer any question about what direction they should take. He had aff irmed\nfor each person the basic purpose of the organization and had redirected their focus onto\nthe need they were committed to meet.\n\nAnother key aspect of writing a values-based mission statement is to position the\nvalues or the need being met as the primary or opening phrase. (This was the case with\nthe Vector,Yale, and WVIA statements discussed earlier.) In this way, people of like values\nare attracted prior to being introduced to the name or function of an organization. By\nstarting with a description of the need that exists and continuing with succinct and pow-\nerful words that tell what the need is and why meeting the need is critical, people who\nshare similar concerns and values are alerted to a deeper purpose. When organizations\nbegin their mission statements with the name of the organization or its principal func-\ntion, some listeners or readers may tune out before the values or purposes are revealed.\nWhen that happens, the opportunity to draw people into the organization\u2019s mission may\nbe delayed or lost. The perceived need must be identif ied f irst.\n\n10 beyond fundraising\n\nc01.qxd (001-016)  3/3/05  3:02 PM  Page 10\n\n\n\nIt is perhaps apocryphal, but there is a story from Black and Decker that sums up this\napproach. It concerns the Black and Decker drill and the way in which sales associates\nare trained to sell it.They are asked,\u201cWhy do people buy a Black and Decker drill?\u201dThe\nanswer most immediately given is \u201cBecause they want a drill.\u201d But that is not the right\nanswer.The reason people buy a Black and Decker drill, the trainees learn, is \u201cBecause they\nwant a hole.\u201d It is the same with nonprof it organizations. People need to see what need the\norganization fulf ills before they will invest in what the organizations does. Just as people\nonly buy a drill if they want a hole, they only invest in organizations if what the organiza-\ntions provide is something they see as important to themselves and/or the community.\n\nThe philosophical mission statement, expressing institutional values, is a fundamental\ntool for creating a solid constituency and donor development program. It can convey a\nmessage that moves people to action and communicates the impact the organization has\nin the community. It is the context for philanthropy and a fundamental building block\nfor development.\n\nDevelopment: The Process of Uncovering Shared Values\n\nThe second element of the model is development, which functions in the larger context\nof philanthropy. Development embraces, but is not synonymous with, fundraising. Often\nconsidered a euphemism for fundraising, development is much more. Philanthropy is\nbased in values, and development is the process of uncovering shared values\u2014 a process that\nincludes their identif ication, nurturing, and reinforcement through publications, actions,\nand community impact. It is a process driven by the importance of providing potential\nand current funders with opportunities to explore and apply these values on behalf of\norganizations.\n\nOrganizations seldom realize the full potential of the development process. Here are\nsome important insights that can be gained with a more inclusive view of development.\n\n\u2022 Development is a series of deliberate activities through which organizations involve\nand retain funders in a donor-investor relationship.\n\n\u2022 Organizations that realize the power of the development process regard their new\nknowledge as the basis for the revitalization of their development and fundraising\npractices.\n\n\u2022 Development is understood as a much larger and deliberate process, characterized\nby patience and focused on initializing, nurturing, and maintaining relationships.\n\n\u2022 Development is the way nonprof its bring their potential and existing donors into\nan understanding of the impact of their investment on the organization and on the\ncommunity.\n\n\u2022 Development creates donor-investors, individual and institutional funders who seek\nand receive a lasting and dynamic relationship with an organization.\n\n\u2022 Development is based on the premise that all giving is a form of community invest-\nment, the return on which is the knowledge that those values which the organiza-\ntion, the community, and the donor-investor share are being acted on.\n\nchapter 1 values 11\n\nc01.qxd (001-016)  3/3/05  3:02 PM  Page 11\n\n\n\nWhy Development Must Be a Priority\nTo be successful at fundraising, it is important to spend a lot of time on the development\nprocess.When development is crafted and pursued as the sensitive and systematic process\nit can be, organizations increase their funding stability.\n\nThose organizations that implement long-term strategies for identifying and devel-\noping the match between donor and institutional values, and then focus on develop-\ning relationships based on those shared values, are better able to withstand change. They\nsurvive, and can even benef it from, shifts in the economy, evolutionary funding patterns,\npendulum political changes, and other forces that mar the capacity of some organizations\nto retain donors.We saw this with the economic downturn of the late twentieth and early\ntwenty-f irst centuries and in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on America on Sep-\ntember 11, 2001. The pressures on organizations were huge;The environment for rais-\ning funds was softer than it had been in decades. Arts organizations in particular suf fered\nas people turned their philanthropy toward what they felt were more \u201cbasic\u201d human\nneeds.The institutions that suf fered but still attracted investment were those universities,\ncultural organizations, schools, and others that had a solid base of good relationship-\nretaining development practices. Unwavering, even in dire times and with an economy\nturned on its head, these organizations continued their outreach, stewardship, and com-\nmunication. Finally, the recovery began, and these organizations were the benef iciaries.\nDonors embraced their constancy.\n\nBut for every organization that meets this description and is admired as a pacesetter\nlocally, nationally, or internationally, there are too many others whose annual campaigns\nf lounder and whose capital campaigns, when attempted, are either extended repeatedly\nto ensure f inancial success or wither into obscurity without reaching their goal.\n\nThe problem is simply this:When development is not a f irm and deliberate practice\nin an organization, when human and f inancial resources are not deployed toward this vital\nfunction, then fundraising ultimately fails.\n\nDef ining Development\nSo what is \u201cdevelopment\u201d? Development consists of those often subtle, frequently in-\ntangible, and not immediately measurable acts that draw donors and volunteers closer \nto the organization and more deeply into an understanding of shared values. These acts\ninclude:\n\n\u2022 A prospect identif ication and qualif ication process that engages board, other vol-\nunteers, and staf f in the regular and willing generation and screening of lists of\npotential donors and volunteers\n\n\u2022 Development of strategies for approaching potential and existing donor-investors\nutilizing a plan of action based on volunteer-staf f resources and donor interests\n\n\u2022 Cultivation of prospects and donors through a well-articulated series of activities,\nmailings, and opportunities based on a strategic cultivation plan to heighten interest\nand build relationships\n\n12 beyond fundraising\n\nc01.qxd (001-016)  3/3/05  3:02 PM  Page 12\n\n\n\n\u2022 Solicitation of gifts using a donor-centered process that results in the transforma-\ntion of prospects into donor-investors\n\n\u2022 Stewardship practices that engage the donor in a way that is desired and appreciated\nby the donor and that strengthen the donor\u2019s understanding of the extent to which\nthere are shared values with the organization\n\n\u2022 Promotion of overall community visibility of the values-based impact the organi-\nzation is making in the community\n\nStrategic implementation of development practices is the critical prelude to successful\nfundraising and is the key to growing the relationship after the gift has been solicited.\n\nThe exposition and application of these practices is a principal focus of this book.\n\nFundraising\nThe file is too long and its contents have been truncated.\n", "title": "Beyond Fundraising New This approach emphasizes the mutual benefits derived from the relationship, aligning the organization&#x27;s needs and goals with the interests and values of the donors.&quot;\n\n### Chapter 5: &quot;Inviting Investment&quot;\n- **On defining Donor-Investor:** &quot;Defining Donor-Investor involves rethinking the traditional donor role as more integral, viewing them as partners who invest not just funds but interest and engagement in the organization.&quot;\n- **On the solicitation process:** &quot;Asking for Investment entails a strategic approach that involves clearly communicating the value and impact of the investment, not just the financial need.&quot;\n- **On broadening participation:** &quot;Inviting Investment: The Solicitation Steps outline a methodical process to engage potential investors, making the case for how their investment will advance the organization&#x27;s mission and their personal or corporate philanthropic goals.&quot;\n\n### Quoted Paragraph:\n&quot;In the chapter &#x27;Inviting Investment&#x27;, the author elaborates on transforming the fundraising narrative from a passive request for help to an active invitation to engage in a meaningful partnership. After an introduction to the problem of overcoming social dilemmas\n\nthrough collective ac t io ,th e  remainder of this article is divided into six sections. The first briefly reviews the\ntheoretical predictions of curently accepted rational choice theory related to social dilemmas. The second\nsection summarizes the challenges to the sole reliance on a complete model of rationality presented by\nextensive erperimental research. In the third section, I discuss two major empirical findings that begin to\nshow how individuals achieve results that are &quot;better than rational&quot; by building conditions where reciprocity,\nreputation  and trust can help to overcome the stong temptations of short-nun self-interest. The fourth\nsection raises the possibiliry of developing second-generation models of rationality, the fifth section develops\nan  initial theoretical sc ea rio , and the  final section concludes by examining the implications o f  placing\nreciprocity reputation  and  trust at the core of an empirically tested, behavioral theory of collective action.\n\nwe are hand-waving at  our central questions. I am\nafraid that  we do a lot of hand-waving.\n\net me start with a provocative statement. You\nwould not be reading this article if it were not for\nsome of our ancestors learning how to undertake\n\ncollective action to solve social dilem mas. Successive\ngenerations have added to the stock of everyday knowl-\nedge about how to instill productive norms of behavior\nin their children and to craft rules to support collective\naction that produces public goods and avoids &quot;trage-\ndies of the commons.&quot;I What our ancestors and con-\ntemporaries have learned about engaging in collective\naction for mutual defense,child rearing,and survival is\nnot , however, understood or explained by the extant\ntheory of collective action.\n\nThe lessons of effective collective action are not\nsimple\u2014as is obvious from human history and the\nimmense tragedies that humans have endured ,as  well\nas the successes we have realized. As global relation-\nships become even more intricately intertwined and\ncomplex,however, our survival becomes more depen-\ndent on empirically grounded scientific understanding.\nWe have not yet developed a behavioral theory of\ncollective action based on models of the individual\nconsistent with empirical evidence about how individ-\nuals make decisions in social-dilemma situations. A\nbehavioralcommitment to theory grounded in empir-\nical inquiry is essential if we are to understand such\nbasic questions as why face-to-face communication so\nconsistently enhances cooperation in social dilemmas\nor how structural variables facilitate or impede cffec-\ntive collective action.\n\nSocial dilemmas occur whenever individuals in inter-\ndependent situations face choices in which the maxi-\nmization of short-term self-interest yields outcomes\nleaving all participants worse off than feasible alterna-\ntives. In a public-good dilemma, for example, all those\nwho would benefit from the provision of a public\ngood\u2014such as pollution control, radio broadcasts  or\nweather forecasting\u2014find it costly to contribute and\nwould prefer others to pay for the good instead. If\neveryone follows the equilibrium strategy, then the\ngood is not provided or  is underprovided  Yet, every-\none would be better off if everyone were to contribute.\n\nSocial dilemmas are found in all aspects of life,\nleading to momentous decisions affecting war and\npeace as well as the mundane relationships of keeping\npromises in everyday life.Social dilemmas are called by\nmany names, including the public-good or collective-\ngood problem(Olson 1965, P.  Samuelson 1954),shirk-\ning(Alchian and Demsetz 1972), the free-rider prob-\nlem(Edney 1979,Grossman and Hart 1980),moral\nhazard(Holmstrom 1982),the credible commitment\ndilemma(Williams, Collins, and Lichbach 1997), gen-\neralized social exchange (Ekch 1974; Emerson 1972a,\n\nYet, the theory of collective action is the central\nsubject of political science  It is the core of the justifi-\ncation for the state. Collective-action problems per-\nvade international relations, face legislators when de-\nvising public budgets,  permeate public bureaucracies,\nand are at the core of explanations of voting, interest\ngroup formation,and citizen control of governments in\na democracy. Ostrom&#x27;s address presents a comprehensive critique and expansion of rational choice theory in the context of collective action. "]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "87d44030bdaa0e6f-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "f8670cd1-e452-4b25-935f-bb8b77be0831", "children": ["3db0fc70-cb4a-434c-9d7a-d1ff32671c2c"]}, "3db0fc70-cb4a-434c-9d7a-d1ff32671c2c": {"id": "3db0fc70-cb4a-434c-9d7a-d1ff32671c2c", "message": {"id": "3db0fc70-cb4a-434c-9d7a-d1ff32671c2c", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1714613495.328827, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Rational choice theory is an economic principle that assumes individuals always make prudent and logical decisions that provide them with the highest amount of personal utility. These decisions are often modeled as attempts to maximize benefits while minimizing costs. The theory is used extensively in economics, sociology, and political science to model human behavior in various contexts, from market transactions to social interactions and political decision-making.\n\n### Key Points of Rational Choice Theory:\n\n1. **Self-Interest**: It posits that individuals act in their own best interest, carefully weighing the costs and benefits of possible alternatives before making decisions.\n\n2. **Utility Maximization**: The core idea is that individuals seek to maximize their utility, or satisfaction, from the choices they make.\n\n3. **Cost-Benefit Analysis**: Decisions are made by comparing the expected costs against the benefits of an action. A rational actor would only engage in an action if the benefits outweigh the costs.\n\n4. **Preferences**: Individuals have clear and consistent preferences among the available choice alternatives that allow them to order these choices.\n\n5. **Optimal Decision**: It assumes that individuals have the capability and necessary information to assess the choices available to them and select the best possible option according to their goals and constraints.\n\n### Applications and Criticisms:\n\n- **Applications**: Rational choice theory is foundational in theories of market behavior and is also used for models in other social sciences, such as sociology and political science, to explain phenomena like voting behavior, crime, and family relationships.\n\n- **Criticisms**: Critics argue that the theory may oversimplify human behavior, ignoring emotional, ethical, and social influences that can also significantly impact decision-making processes. Critics also point out that access to complete information and the capacity to process it are often unrealistic.\n\nDespite criticisms, rational choice theory remains a fundamental concept used to understand and predict decisions in a broad array of academic fields and practical applications."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true
