After an introduction to the problem of overcoming social dilemmas\n\nthrough collective ac t io ,th e  remainder of this article is divided into six sections. The first briefly reviews the\ntheoretical predictions of curently accepted rational choice theory related to social dilemmas. The second\nsection summarizes the challenges to the sole reliance on a complete model of rationality presented by\nextensive erperimental research. In the third section, I discuss two major empirical findings that begin to\nshow how individuals achieve results that are &quot;better than rational&quot; by building conditions where reciprocity,\nreputation  and trust can help to overcome the stong temptations of short-nun self-interest. The fourth\nsection raises the possibiliry of developing second-generation models of rationality, the fifth section develops\nan  initial theoretical sc ea rio , and the  final section concludes by examining the implications o f  placing\nreciprocity reputation  and  trust at the core of an empirically tested, behavioral theory of collective action.\n\nwe are hand-waving at  our central questions. I am\nafraid that  we do a lot of hand-waving.\n\net me start with a provocative statement. You\nwould not be reading this article if it were not for\nsome of our ancestors learning how to undertake\n\ncollective action to solve social dilem mas. Successive\ngenerations have added to the stock of everyday knowl-\nedge about how to instill productive norms of behavior\nin their children and to craft rules to support collective\naction that produces public goods and avoids &quot;trage-\ndies of the commons.&quot;I What our ancestors and con-\ntemporaries have learned about engaging in collective\naction for mutual defense,child rearing,and survival is\nnot , however, understood or explained by the extant\ntheory of collective action.\n\nThe lessons of effective collective action are not\nsimple\u2014as is obvious from human history and the\nimmense tragedies that humans have endured ,as  well\nas the successes we have realized. As global relation-\nships become even more intricately intertwined and\ncomplex,however, our survival becomes more depen-\ndent on empirically grounded scientific understanding.\nWe have not yet developed a behavioral theory of\ncollective action based on models of the individual\nconsistent with empirical evidence about how individ-\nuals make decisions in social-dilemma situations. A\nbehavioralcommitment to theory grounded in empir-\nical inquiry is essential if we are to understand such\nbasic questions as why face-to-face communication so\nconsistently enhances cooperation in social dilemmas\nor how structural variables facilitate or impede cffec-\ntive collective action.\n\nSocial dilemmas occur whenever individuals in inter-\ndependent situations face choices in which the maxi-\nmization of short-term self-interest yields outcomes\nleaving all participants worse off than feasible alterna-\ntives. In a public-good dilemma, for example, all those\nwho would benefit from the provision of a public\ngood\u2014such as pollution control, radio broadcasts  or\nweather forecasting\u2014find it costly to contribute and\nwould prefer others to pay for the good instead. If\neveryone follows the equilibrium strategy, then the\ngood is not provided or  is underprovided  Yet, every-\none would be better off if everyone were to contribute.\n\nSocial dilemmas are found in all aspects of life,\nleading to momentous decisions affecting war and\npeace as well as the mundane relationships of keeping\npromises in everyday life.Social dilemmas are called by\nmany names, including the public-good or collective-\ngood problem(Olson 1965, P.  Samuelson 1954),shirk-\ning(Alchian and Demsetz 1972), the free-rider prob-\nlem(Edney 1979,Grossman and Hart 1980),moral\nhazard(Holmstrom 1982),the credible commitment\ndilemma(Williams, Collins, and Lichbach 1997), gen-\neralized social exchange (Ekch 1974; Emerson 1972a,\n\nYet, the theory of collective action is the central\nsubject of political science  It is the core of the justifi-\ncation for the state. Collective-action problems per-\nvade international relations, face legislators when de-\nvising public budgets,  permeate public bureaucracies,\nand are at the core of explanations of voting, interest\ngroup formation,and citizen control of governments in\na democracy. Social Science\n\njournal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/erss\n\nPerspectives\n\nBeyond the tragedy of the commons: Reframing effective climate change\ngovernance\n\nAnthony Patt\nETH Z\u00fcrich, Switzerland\n\nA R T I C L E I N F O\n\nKeywords:\nClimate policy\nTragedy of the commons\nGlobal commons problem\nTechnological transitions\n\nA B S T R A C T\n\nThe tragedy of the commons provides a powerful narrative for a class of environmental problems, and serves to\nframe them in a way that allows people to identify effective solution strategies. But the problem frame also rests\non a set of factual and value-based assumptions, and is inappropriate to guide decision-making when these\nassumptions are violated. The climate change mitigation challenge \u2013 reducing greenhouse gas emissions, mainly\nfrom the energy sector, to limit global warming to less than 1.5 or 2 \u00b0C \u2013 violates these assumptions. Climate\nchange requires us not to reduce, but to completely prohibit greenhouse gas emissions. Before any such\nprohibition is feasible, it is first essential to develop a clean energy system that can meet our basic needs. The\nmain barriers to this are not economic, but rather are associated with evolving knowledge, networks, and\ninstitutions. Framing climate change in evolutionary terms can help us to appraise policy options more\neffectively, and ultimate identify those that get us where we need to go.\n\n1. The tragedy of the commons\n\nThe biologist and ethnic nationalist Garrett Hardin wanted society\nto restrict people\u2019s reproductive freedom, and believed that only those\nparents who would raise their children the right way should be entitled\nto have babies [1,2]. To support this politically charged belief, Hardin\ndeveloped an argument based on the idea of the tragedy of the commons,\na game theoretic model involving farmers\u2019 letting their cows graze on\nthe communally owned village green [3]. Every farmer obtains the full\nbenefit of placing an extra cow on the commons to graze, while\nsuffering only a small share of the cost to the community as a whole,\nin terms of less grass being available to the other cows. Overgrazing is\nthe inevitable equilibrium, unless the community as a whole steps in.\nLimiting the number of cows, and ideally allocating them to those\nfarmers who can manage them most profitably, is the obvious solution.\nThe lesson transferred well to the point Hardin was trying to make\nabout people in his now famous article.\n\nToday, few would use a tragedy of the commons framing, or related\nterms such as commons problem, common pool resource problem, or\nexternalities problem, to describe the issue of human population growth.\nThis is largely because the world has witnessed birthrates falling\nglobally, on most continents to below replacement levels, as a result\nof factors Hardin didn\u2019t consider: the education of women, reductions in\ninfant mortality, and urbanization [4,5]. But most analysts do use\nHardin\u2019s idea to describe other environmental problems, most notably\nclimate change, and based on this framing suggest a strategy similar to\n\nwhat Hardin advocated [6]. The framing may be appropriate for some\nof these problems, fisheries management being an example that comes\nto mind. But it is not appropriate for climate change, and the sooner we\nstop framing climate change in this way, the better.\n\nAs a starting point, it is worth considering what the key aspects of a\ncommons problem actually are. Hardin himself described four, and\nthese are as valid today as they were then. First, of course, there needs\nto be a common pool resource, such as the grass on a village green, or\nthe global carrying capacity for people. Second, there needs to be a use\nof that resource, or an activity that depletes it, that is legitimate and\nvaluable, accepted by society at large. In Hardin\u2019s model, we do want\ncows to graze on the village green, as long as they do so productively,\njust as we do want a planet that is home to people. In fact, because the\nuse is so valuable, we want to ensure that it takes place in a manner that\nis both optimal and sustainable. Third, the common-pool nature of the\nresource has to be the thing that leads people to overuse or over-deplete\nthe resource, to the point that is clearly suboptimal, perhaps even\nexceeding its sustainable limits. Fourth, there cannot be a technical\nsolution. By this, Hardin meant that it is not possible to use technology\nto expand the resource in order to continually accommodate the\ngrowing use.\n\nThe tragedy of the commons acts a problem frame. The effect of a\nproblem frame is to take a complex issue \u2013 which affects multiple values\nand can be considered from a variety of perspectives \u2013 and to simplify it\naround one particular conceptualization, leading to one particular\nsolution strategy [7]. In the case of this framing, it is the third aspect\n\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.erss.2017.05.023\nReceived 16 May 2017; Accepted 18 May 2017\n\nE-mail address: anthony.patt@usys.ethz.ch.\n\nEnergy Research &amp; Social Science 34 (2017) 1\u20133\n\nAvailable online 27 May 2017\n2214-6296/ \u00a9 2017 The Author(s). Published by Elsevier Ltd. This is an open access article under the CC BY license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/BY/4.0/).\n\nT\n\nhttp://www.sciencedirect.com/science/journal/22146296\nhttp://www.elsevier.com/locate/erss\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.erss.2017.05.023\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.erss.2017.05.023\nmailto:anthony.patt@usys.ethz.ch\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.erss.2017.05.023\nhttp://crossmark.crossref.org/dialog/?doi=10.1016/j.erss.2017.05.023&amp;domain=pdf\n\n\nlisted in the paragraph above that is crucial. The common-pool own-\nership structure, meaning that agents do not pay the full cost of their\nuse, is seen as the driving force behind their overuse. Framing a\nproblem as a tragedy of the commons automatically implies that if one\ncould privatize the ownership structure, or make the agents pay the full\ncosts to society of their use of the resource, then an optimal outcome\nwould be achieved. In the case of a village green, the easy solution is to\ndivide it up with fences, and have each subdivided plot belong to a\nsingle farmer. In the case of a resource that cannot be subdivided so\neasily, like the global carrying capacity for humans, then the solution is\nonly slightly more complicated. Either one has to establish a limited\nnumber of rights to use the resource, and allocate these to people in\nadvance, or one has to charge people ex post for their use of the\nresource. An important feature of the model is that the solution\nincreases the resource\u2019s overall productivity. And that means that as\nlong as the allocation mechanism or tax is fair, then reaching an\nagreement to privatize the use rights or internalize their costs should be\npolitically feasible.\n\nBut the usefulness of such policy guidance depends on the under-\nlying applicability of the problem frame. The presence of a common\npool resource does not guarantee that Hardin\u2019s solution strategy is the\nbest; the problem frame ceases to provide useful guidance if any of the\nother three criteria are violated. A case that illustrates failure on the\nsecond of the four criteria is the act of murdering one\u2019s neighbor. This\ndepletes the common pool resource of public safety, but murder is not\nan activity that we want, so we don\u2019t solve it by imposing a tax or\nallocating a limited number of permits. We prohibit it. To illustrate\nfailure on the third criterion, drinking alcohol is a behavior that we\ntolerate in moderation, and even encourage in some situations, but\nwhen people get drunk and start breaking things, they become a public\nnuisance. Yet we don\u2019t believe that internalizing the cost of drunken\nbehavior will get the person on the verge of intoxication to say no to\nanother drink. So we address it by other means, including charging\nbartenders with cutting people off, and providing treatment programs\nfor alcoholism. To illustrate failure on the fourth criterion, the local\npublic school may be overcrowded, but we can solve this by enlarging\nthe building and hiring more teachers. So we do that, rather than\nlimiting the number of places available or imposing high school fees.\nFailure on any of these criteria matters. Climate change fails on all\nthree.\n\n2. Why climate change fails the tragedy of the commons criteria\n\nMany people see the 2015 Paris Agreement as representing a\nturning point in climate governance, but in fact the events that\nforeshadowed Paris occurred a decade prior to then, culminating in\n2007. It was then that the idea of the 2 \u00b0C target gained popularity,\nbased on risk management arguments, and was incorporated into a\nglobal action plan agreed to in Bali, Indonesia, at the closing of a failed\nset of negotiations to extend or replace the Kyoto Protocol [8\u201310]. Paris\nbuilt on this decision, and added an additional level of ambition by\nsuggesting the desirability of limiting climate change to 1.5 \u00b0C. More\nimportantly, Paris set up a process that could help countries to take the\nsteps to achieve one or the other, in terms of a regular \u201cglobal stock\ntake,\u201d as well as a set of mechanisms to provide financial and capacity-\nbuilding support to developing countries.\n\nThe one thing that the Paris Agreement does not include is a set of\nnegotiated binding national targets, of the kind that are the heart of the\nKyoto Protocol. In fact, the failed desire to include such binding targets\nis what led to the eight-year delay, starting in Bali. And yet this failure\nshould not surprise us, for a simple reason. The tragedy of the commons\nframing suggests that negotiating binding targets should be politically\nfeasible, with the main hurdle being the identification of a mutually\nacceptable allocation rule for the net benefits. But this presupposes that\nthe global target is one that will maximize the value to society of\nwhatever activity it is that degrades the common pool resource. Partial\n\ndecarbonization as per Kyoto could take place by eliminating ineffi-\nciencies in the energy system, and arguably could deliver immediate net\neconomic benefits; negotiating the allocation rule took less than two\nyears. Achieving the Paris targets of 2 \u00b0C or 1.5 \u00b0C, however, requires\nthat net anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases into the atmo-\nsphere cease entirely in the second half of this century [11]. Finding\nimmediate net benefits to allocate that are associated with a complete\nhalting of emissions is more or less impossible, and so negotiating such\nan agreement required convincing people to pay attention to large\nbenefits anticipated in the future, in some cases centuries hence [12,8].\nSo the temperature target qualitatively changed the character of\nnegotiations, making them far more difficult, arguably impossible.\nMore fundamentally, the need to eliminate emissions entirely, essen-\ntially as soon as possible, makes those emissions something that society\nwill no longer tolerate. So climate change fails the second of the four\ncriteria Hardin identified, just like murder.\n\nThere has been another major change since about 2007, and that is\nthe recognition that the medium-term costs of eliminating greenhouse\ngas emissions are likely to be trivial, and may in fact be negative, even\nbefore considering the long-term benefits from avoided climate impacts\n[13,14]. What drove this recognition was the realization from the field\nof evolutionary economics that policies to expand renewable energy\nalso make them cheaper [15,16]. This fact has become especially salient\nlately, as the costs of supplying energy from some renewable resources\nhave fallen to below those of fossil fuels [17], especially if one takes\ninto account local environmental effects such as air pollution or water\ndemand [18]. A study in the United States, for example, examined the\navoided local and regional environmental impacts associated with\ninstalling wind and solar power instead of new coal capacity, and\nfound the value of those impacts to be far larger than the difference in\ncost between the two technologies [19]. As another example, the costs\nto own and drive an electric car charged by wind or solar power are\napproaching parity with those of a conventional gasoline model, at least\nunder some conditions [20].\n\nThese trends suggest two additional ways in which the tragedy of\nthe commons framing fails for climate change. First, there is no longer a\nnecessary misalignment of incentives between the emitters of green-\nhouse gases and society at large. Every country, with the possible\nexception of major oil and gas exporters, has reason to mitigate climate\nchange and transform its national energy sector away from fossil fuels,\nregardless of what other countries may do. Every household will soon\nhave a financial incentive to stop burning oil and gas, regardless of\nwhat their neighbors do. So if fossil fuels are still in business, it will not\nbe because of an unjust cost advantage, born from the existence of an\nexternality. Climate change is like the example of public drunkenness:\ninternalizing the cost will not change anything qualitatively. Second, it\nnow appears that a technical solution does exist for climate change.\nIntegrated assessment models suggest that by switching to non-fossil\nenergy sources, we can continue to see global economic activity grow,\nat roughly the same pace, even as greenhouse gas emissions come to a\nhalt [21]. Climate change is like enlarging the public school.\n\n3. Framing today\u2019s challenge in evolutionary terms\n\nBut we still have a problem needing to be solved. Using electric cars\nas an example, a household may soon have a financial incentive to\nswitch over from their gasoline model, but it will not do so unless there\nis a dense network of charging stations where they want to take long\ntrips. At the same time, there is no business case to install such a\nnetwork as long as the number of electric cars on the road remains low.\nThis is a chicken and egg problem: you need a chicken to get an egg, but\nan egg to get a chicken. Similar problems exist across the energy sector.\nAt the most general level, we need to prohibit greenhouse gas\nemissions, which almost certainly means prohibiting fossil fuels. But\nwhich comes first: prohibition, or clean energy? Before prohibition can\nbe politically and socially feasible, we need a clean energy system that\n\nA. Patt Energy Research &amp; Social Science 34 (2017) 1\u20133\n\n2\n\n\n\nis good enough to sustain us. Yet given more than a century already\nspent improving and optimizing an energy system based on fossil fuels,\nthe first steps towards a clean energy system are necessarily expensive,\nclunky, and unreliable. Most of the improvements to the clean energy\nsystem \u2013 built around new knowledge, networks, and institutions \u2013 only\ncome once we start relying on it. Progress can occur, but without policy\nintervention, it will be slow. It took millions of years to get a chicken\negg when the starting point was a dinosaur. Accelerating evolution is\nthe key challenge for climate policy.\n\nJust as the tragedy of the commons framing offered clear guidance\nin terms of the appropriate policy instruments, so too does an\nevolutionary framing, based on insights from the emerging scientific\nstudy of socio-technical transitions [22]. Our policy instruments need to\nbe those that build the new knowledge, networks, and institutions that\nwill enable a clean energy system to function smoothly and affordably,\nwhich is a prerequisite to phasing out fossil fuels. When we think about\nall of the policies that support renewable energy innovation and\ndeployment \u2013 state-sponsored R &amp;D, tax credits or feed-in tariffs for\nproject developers, and streamlined permitting processes for green\ninfrastructure \u2013 that is exactly what is going on. As they create a new\nsystem that is viable, these policies lay the groundwork for a second\ngeneration of sectoral regulations, already beginning to appear, which\nprevent new investment into fossil fuel infrastructure. If you frame\nclimate change as an evolutionary problem, it is this sequence of policy\ninstruments that makes the most sense [23].\n\nThe issue of how we frame climate change mitigation is important,\nprecisely because the two framings point us in different directions with\nrespect to policy. When there is a true tragedy of the commons, then\nneo-classical economics and game theory provide a solid basis to favor\nmarket-based instruments, those that allocate limited rights to deplete\nthe resource or internalize the costs of doing so [24]. Confusion can\narise, however, because proponents of market-based instruments also\nsuggest that these will provide the needed stimulus for innovation,\npromoting systemic change [25,26]. But just because these instruments\nare the best solution to one kind of problem does not mean they are\nvery good or effective with respect to another. In fact, a growing\nliterature shows that they aren\u2019t, and that the effective policies to\nstimulate a transition are those that directly support the development of\nnew knowledge, networks, and institutions, directly addressing the\nbarriers to systemic change [27]. The choice of how we frame climate\nchange dictates the terms by which we evaluate the relative strengths\nand weaknesses of the different possible solution strategies. Judged by\nthe appropriate criteria, market instruments are generally a poor fit.\n\nThe tragedy of the commons framing made sense at a time when we\nbelieved that people needed to adjust the energy system at the margins,\nand believed that the cost of doing so would be high. We no longer\nbelieve these things. The atmosphere may be a common pool resource,\nbut using it as a place to put our greenhouse gas emissions is no longer\nsomething for which we have any long-term rights to allocate. To\nprohibit dumping our greenhouse gases there, we first need to accel-\nerate a technological transition towards non-fossil sources of energy, for\nwhich the main barriers have to do with knowledge and networks,\nrather than an inherent difference in cost. Policies providing active and\ndirect governmental support for new technologies and technological\nsystems can change the conditions that hold the new technologies back.\nIn fact they have already done a great deal; they have led to a dramatic\ndecline in the costs of key energy technologies, and contributed to the\npossibility that global emissions have already peaked. There is still\nmore work to be done, and we can solve climate change if we build on\nwhat we have learned. At all costs, we should resist the temptation to\nreverse course because the policies don\u2019t fit one man\u2019s convenient story\nof too many cows on a village green.\n\nAcknowledgment\n\nFunding for the development of the ideas expressed in this article\n\ncame from European Research Council Starting Grant number 313553.\n\nReferences\n\n[1] G. Published here under license by the Resilience Alliance.\nBeier, C., A. L. Lovecraft, and T. Chapin. 2009. Growth and collapse of a resource system: an adaptive\ncycle of change in public lands governance and forest management in Alaska. Ecology and Society 14(2):\n5. [online] URL: http://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art5/\n\nSynthesis\nGrowth and Collapse of a Resource System: an Adaptive Cycle of Change\nin Public Lands Governance and Forest Management in Alaska\n\nColin M. Beier 1,2, Amy Lauren Lovecraft 1, and F. Stuart Chapin, III 1\n\nABSTRACT. Large-scale government efforts to develop resources for societal benefit have often\nexperienced cycles of growth and decline that leave behind difficult social and ecological legacies. To\nunderstand the origins and outcomes of these failures of resource governance, scholars have applied the\nframework of the adaptive cycle. In this study, we used the adaptive cycle as a diagnostic approach to trace\nthe drivers and dynamics of forest governance surrounding a boom\u2013bust sequence of industrial forest\nmanagement in one of the largest-scale resource systems in U.S. history: the Tongass National Forest in\nsoutheastern Alaska. Our application of the adaptive cycle combined a historical narrative tracing dynamics\nin political, institutional, and economic subsystems and a longitudinal analysis of an indicator of overall\nsystem behavior (timber harvests). We found that federal policies in concert with global market changes\ndrove transformative change in both forest governance (policy making) and forest management (practices),\nthrough creation and dissolution of subsidized long-term lease contracts. Evidence of the systemic resilience\nprovided by these leases was found in the analysis of industry responses to market volatility before and\nafter Tongass-specific federal reforms. Although the lease contracts stabilized the Tongass system for a\nperiod of time, they fostered a growing degree of rigidity that contributed to a severe industrial collapse\nand the subsequent emergence of complex social traps. Broader lessons from the Tongass suggest that\nlarge-scale changes occurred only when the nested economic and policy cycles were in coherence, and a\nsystemic effort to minimize social and ecological variability ultimately resulted in catastrophic collapse of\ngovernance. This collapse resulted in a pervasive and challenging legacy that prevents Tongass\nreorganization and limits the adaptive capacity of the larger social\u2013ecological system of southeastern\nAlaska. Although this legacy has inhibited system renewal for two decades, recent trends indicate the\nemergence of new opportunities for progress toward sustainable governance of the Tongass National Forest.\n\nKey Words: adaptive cycle; Alaska; forest management; resource governance; rigidity traps; U.S. National\nForests\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nGovernment efforts to stimulate the development of\nnatural resources for public benefit often seek to\nimplement a vision at grand scales that, over time,\ncreates a cycle of dependency that undermines the\noriginal social purpose as well as the resource base\nthat was intended to be sustained. In the United\nStates, this has occurred with respect to agriculture\n(Light et al. 1995), forestry (Repetto 1998, Trosper\n2003), fisheries (Francis and Reiger 1995, Pauly et\nal. 2005), water (Ostrom 1990, Lee 1995), and many\nother types of resource systems (Holling and Meffe\n1996). Similar cycles of dependency have emerged\n\nthrough international aid programs to developing\nnations that were intended to create self-sufficiency\nthrough resource development. Although the goals\nof these programs are often socially admirable and\nprovide an economic stimulus to initiate changes\nthat would otherwise lack the resources to emerge\n\u2014i.e., to escape from poverty traps (Carpenter and\nBrock 2008)\u2014they often result in challenging\nsocial traps (Costanza 1987) that can constrain\noptions for future generations. Why have these\ngovernance efforts failed so consistently, and what\nlessons can be learned that would enlighten efforts\nto address new frontiers of resource governance and\npublic welfare in a rapidly changing world?\n\n1University of Alaska-Fairbanks, 2SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry\n\nThis content downloaded from \n\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd24.162.145.200 on Mon, 22 Mar 2021 15:33:51 UTC\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \n\nAll use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms\n\nhttp://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art5/\nmailto:cbeier@esf.edu\nmailto:ffall@uaf.edu\nmailto:terry.chapin@uaf.edu\n\n\nEcology and Society 14(2): 5\nhttp://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art5/\n\nIn this article, we analyze the rise, collapse, and\naftermath of one of the largest resource governance\nprograms in the history of the United States:\nindustrial timber production in the Tongass National\nForest (Tongass) of southeastern Alaska. Although\nlarge-scale industrial forestry emerged as a\nmechanism for stimulating social welfare and\neconomic growth, the Tongass has become one of\nthe most controversial issues of public land\nmanagement in the United States (Wilkinson 1997).\nAs such, its story has been framed in several ways:\nas the central theme in the history and purpose of\nthe U.S. Forest Service in Alaska (Rakestraw 1989);\nas an acute example of political influence,\nmismanagement, and corruption resulting in\nenvironmental degradation (Durbin 1999); as a\ncomplex situation governed by entrenched\ninfluences and acrimonious personal relationships,\nas described by a former agency chief (Steen 2004);\nas a local drama of lost jobs and livelihoods due to\n\u201ceconomic vandalism\u201d by environmentalists\n(Soderberg and DuRette 1988); and as a study of\ncumulative regulatory complications and policy\nreforms resulting in conflicted governance and a\n\u201cdeadlock\u201d among institutions and stakeholder\ngroups (Nie 2006).\n\nAlthough each account yields valuable insights,\nthey present an incomplete and often normative\npicture of the Tongass case and its broader\nimplications for the regional social\u2013ecological\nsystem (SES) of southeastern Alaska; and therefore,\nprovide little guidance on how resource systems\nmight be more effectively governed for long-term\nsustainability and greater public benefit. In this\narticle, we present the first analysis that examines\nthe links among policy, institutions, economies, and\necosystems that shaped the governance of the\nTongass during the 20th century. We apply a\nresilience lens and use the framework of the\nadaptive cycle (Holling and Gunderson 2002) as a\ndiagnostic tool to investigate the nested attributes\nof the Tongass system (Ostrom 2007). Building on\na previous group of adaptive-cycle studies of\nmanagement and governance systems (Gunderson\net al. 1995), we (1) developed an adaptive-cycle\nnarrative of the Tongass coupled with a quantitative\nindicator of system behavior (annual timber\nharvests), (2) traced the adaptive cycles of policy,\ninstitutional, and economic subsystems to identify\nsynergistic feedbacks that drove transformative\nchange at larger scales, and (3) compared adaptive-\ncycle interactions among subsystems to identify\nsources of resilience and vulnerability.\n\nObjectives and Key Questions\n\nIn this case study, we apply the adaptive cycle as\nboth a theoretical framework and a diagnostic\nmethod to reveal the dynamics and interactions of\na resource governance and management system\nnested within a larger SES. We chose the adaptive\ncycle because the Tongass boom\u2013bust cycle typified\nthe \u201cpathology of resource management\u201d (Holling\nand Meffe 1996), characterized by a cyclical pattern\nof dynamics that links ecological (resource) and\nsocial (governance) systems in a higher-order\ncoupled system (SES) (Gunderson et al. 1995,\nHolling et al. 2002b). The adaptive cycle explains\nthe dynamics of a system that is initiated\n(organization [\u03b1]), mobilizes and develops (growth\n[r]), attains a stable configuration (conservation\n[K]), changes to a different structure (collapse [\u2126]),\nand begins the process anew (reorganization [\u03b1]).\nOur focus is on the coupled cycles of change in\ngovernance (through policy and leadership),\nresource management (through practices and\nplanning), and private industry (through processing\nand sale of forest products), and their overall\nimpacts on the southeastern Alaska SES. The\nadaptive-cycle framework supports the systematic\nidentification of key interactions and feedbacks\namong system components that drove system\ndynamics, allowing us to address the following\nquestions:\n\n\u25cf What factors (ecological, economic, cultural,\npolitical) had the greatest overall influence\non stability and change in Tongass\ngovernance and management?\n \n\n\u25cf What aspects of Tongass governance (via\npolicy) and forest management (via practice)\nwere especially vulnerable to drivers of\nchange?\n \n\n\u25cf How did the system stabilize itself against\nexternal perturbation?\n \n\n\u25cf What was the source of this resilience and\nhow was it eventually lost? Was collapse\ntriggered by changes in one or many aspects\nof the system?\n \n\n\u25cf What aspects of the Tongass system resulted\nin the social\u2013ecological legacy that currently\ninhibits renewal toward a more sustainable\nsystem of forest governance?\n\nThis content downloaded from \n\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd24.162.145.200 on Mon, 22 Mar 2021 15:33:51 UTC\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \n\nAll use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms\n\nhttp://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art5/\n\n\nEcology and Society 14(2): 5\nhttp://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art5/\n\n \n\u25cf How does this legacy inhibit progress? How\n\ncan this legacy be overcome to facilitate\nsystem renewal and restore adaptive\ncapacity?\n\nA Systems Framework\n\nWe define the \u201cTongass system\u201d as a coupled\nsystem of governance (the set of structures and\nprocesses by which people make decisions and\nshare power) and management (the set of actions\nthat manipulate a system to achieve desired\noutcomes) nested within in the larger SES. We\nrecognize three nested subsystems of the Tongass\nsystem (Fig. 1): the \u201cinstitutional subsystem,\u201d\nincluding the U.S. Forest Service, principally the\nTongass administration; the \u201cpolicy subsystem\u201d\nthat governs Tongass management and land-use\ndecision making; and the \u201ceconomic subsystem\u201d\nthat defines the structure, capacity, and efficiency\nof the regional industry and market value of its\nproducts. Each subsystem may experience adaptive\ncycles of change influenced by internal components\nand drivers of change (e.g., Tongass managers and\ntheir preferences, legislation specific to Tongass\ngovernance, and economic factors pertaining to\nlocal industry) as well as external components and\ndrivers (e.g., national leadership in the Forest\nService, federal legislation, and global timber\nmarkets) (Fig. 1). Our approach is to explain larger-\nscale SES dynamics by describing the subsystem\ndynamics, which are more easily observed and can\ngenerate transformative feedbacks at larger scales\n(Walker et al. 2004).\n\nIn this article, governance concerns the decisions\nmade regarding the policy goals for the Tongass in\nthe context of a broader vision and purpose for the\nregion of southeastern Alaska, specifically its\ncommunities and natural resources. Management is\nthe active implementation of specific practices, such\nas industrial even-aged forestry, to reach these\nobjectives. Governance emerges primarily from the\npolicy subsystem and management emerges\nprimarily from the institutional subsystem, although\nthe two are functionally coupled.\n\nFor this case study, we narrowly define the regional\necosystem with a focus on environmental factors\nthat directly influenced governance and management,\n\nand the processes that controlled ecological\nresponses to management practices. These include\nthe condition of the old-growth forest resource,\nspatial variation in forest productivity, and the\nremote and rugged geography of the region that\nshaped the options available for resource\ndevelopment (Fig. 1). We did not address\nsuccessional dynamics because these primary\nforests were largely unmodified by human actions\nwhen industrial forestry began, and because second-\ngrowth forests did not reach a harvestable age during\nthe short lifespan of industrial forestry in the region.\nHanley et al. (2005) and Beier et al. (2008) address\nthe longer-term ecological implications of clearcut\nharvesting and even-aged management practices in\nthe temperate rainforests of southeastern Alaska.\n\nAPPROACH\n\nUsing this system structure and the adaptive-cycle\nframework, we developed a historical narrative of\nthe Tongass system that traces a complete loop of\nthe adaptive cycle, beginning with the creation of\nthe Tongass National Forest (1908), passage of key\nlegislation fostering industrial development (1947),\nboom years during which timber production peaked\n(1970), collapse of the regional industry (1997), and\nthe contentious stalemate of the present day (2009).\nIn parallel with this narrative, we traced system\ndynamics using annual timber outputs, a\nquantitative variable reflecting an emergent\nproperty of the Tongass system. Based on this\nlongitudinal analysis (Fig. 2) and a historical\ntimeline of key events in Tongass governance and\nmanagement (Appendix 1), we described the\nadaptive cycle of each subsystem, the cross-\nlinkages among adaptive cycles, and events that\ntriggered \u201ctipping points\u201d in the larger SES. In\nsummarizing the narrative, we address our research\nquestions and revisit Holling and Meffe\u2019s (1996)\n\u201cpathology of resource management\u201d concept to\ndraw broader conclusions from the Tongass case.\n\nSYSTEMS NARRATIVE\n\nOrganization Phase [\u03b1] 1908\u20131947\n\nIn the first half of the 20th century, the foundations\nof the Tongass system emerged during its\norganization [\u03b1] phase\u2014analogous to the \u201cpioneer\u201d\nstage of forest succession, when several interacting\n\nThis content downloaded from \n\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd24.162.145.200 on Mon, 22 Mar 2021 15:33:51 UTC\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \n\nAll use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms\n\nhttp://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art5/\n\n\nEcology and Society 14(2): 5\nhttp://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art5/\n\nFig. 1. Conceptual diagram of the southeastern Alaska social\u2013ecological system (SES), with an\nemphasis on the Tongass system, including components and drivers of change of interest in the case\nstudy.\n\nfactors dictate the organization of the mature forest\nin terms of structure, function, and composition. In\nthe Tongass, the arrival of new actors, conditions,\nand drivers of change interacted to dictate the\nstructure, dynamics, and controls over the future\nsystem.\n\nDuring the 19th century, forests in southeastern\nAlaska were harvested only for local use, primarily\nto support fur traders, the salmon industry, and the\n\nGold Rush. In 1908\u2014a decade after the U.S. Forest\nService was established, four decades after Alaska\u2019s\npurchase from Russia, and coincident with public\nrecognition of Alaska\u2019s natural wealth in gold,\nsalmon, and timber\u2014the 6.7 million acre Tongass\nNational Forest was established, and within a year,\nPresident Theodore Roosevelt and U.S. Forest\nService founder Gifford Pinchot expanded the\nTongass by an additional 8.7 million acres to create\nthe largest national forest in the United States. From\n\nThis content downloaded from \n\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd24.162.145.200 on Mon, 22 Mar 2021 15:33:51 UTC\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \n\nAll use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms\n\nhttp://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art5/\n\n\nEcology and Society 14(2): 5\nhttp://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art5/\n\nFig. 2. Longitudinal analysis of annual timber harvest outputs from the Tongass National Forest and\nsubsystem dynamics (see Appendix 2), divided into the four phases of the adaptive cycle: organization,\ngrowth, conservation, and collapse.\n\nits earliest beginnings, Tongass managers were\npioneers of a broad vision to encourage regional\npopulation growth and establish a clear U.S.\npresence in Alaska by developing a strong, self-\nsufficient economy based on timber production\n(Rakestraw 1989, Nie 2006). The roots of the\nTongass approach\u2014to convert old-growth forests\nto \u201cmore manageable\u201d second-growth stands, while\nfueling a forest-products industry based on pulp and\nsawtimber\u2014were evident upon completion of the\nfirst federal inventories. In 1909, Tongass officials\nsuggested that pulp production was the best use of\nold-growth rainforests, that \u201cthe chief need is for a\n\nplanned harvest of the mature timber\u201d (Rakestraw\n1989:23), and recommended revision of federal law\nto allow the sale of National Forest lands for\ndevelopment.\n\nHowever, this industrial approach required\nsignificant private investment to establish a\nsufficient economy of scale to make Tongass timber\nprofitable. Despite the pursuit of such investments\nby key figures, including U.S. Forest Service Chief\nWilliam Greeley in the 1920s and Alaska Regional\nForester Frank Heintzleman throughout the 1930s\nand 1940s, these efforts were thwarted by economic\n\nThis content downloaded from \n\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd24.162.145.200 on Mon, 22 Mar 2021 15:33:51 UTC\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \n\nAll use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms\n\nhttp://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art5/\n\n\nEcology and Society 14(2): 5\nhttp://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art5/\n\nconstraints, including poor regional infrastructure,\ndistance from markets, and the Great Depression.\n\nWorld War II and its aftermath provided the catalyst\nto implement industrial forestry in the Tongass,\nbecause American wartime demand for airplane\nlumber exceeded supplies in Oregon and\nWashington, which had been depleted during World\nWar I. To capture this opportunity, Heintzleman\nsought the advice of timber-industry executives in\npresenting his case for what became the Alaska\nSpruce Log Program (ASLP). Created as an agency\nin 1942, ASLP supplied mills in the continental\nUnited States with high-grade Sitka spruce logs\nfrom the Tongass. At the time, Tongass logging\noccurred primarily by hand-felling the best trees in\naccessible sites, such as beach fringes and river\nbottoms. However, the collective opinion of\nTongass managers, many of whom were\nprofessionally trained foresters, was that clearcutting\nwas a far superior method (Rakestraw 1989).\nTaylor\u2019s (1935) Ecology article provided scientific\njustification for the change from high grading to\nclearcutting in the Alaskan rainforest. With this\njustification, Tongass managers shifted the\nsilvicultural prescription to clearcutting and sought\nto demonstrate the economic viability of harvesting\nthe low-grade timber that comprised the majority of\nthe Tongass timber base.\n\nIn the 18 months of ASLP operation, the program\nexported 38.5 million board feet (MBF) of high-\ngrade spruce to continental U.S. mills, and\ntransferred 46 MBF of lower (utility) grade material\nto local Alaska mills. The ASLP-legislated target\nwas 100 MBF/year of high-grade Sitka spruce, with\nno mention of low-grade materials whatsoever.\nAlthough short lived, the wartime program\ndemonstrated the commercial viability of both\nsawtimber and utility-grade materials from the\nTongass. It also forged strong relationships among\nTongass officials, national policy makers, and\ntimber-industry representatives (Rakestraw 1989).\n\nIn summary, the organization [\u03b1] phase consisted\nof a series of events that initiated adaptive cycles\nsimultaneously in the institutional, policy, and\neconomic subsystems. These adaptive cycles in the\nsubsystems defined the future configuration of the\nTongass system and prepared it for transformation\n(Appendix 2). Key actors in these subsystems\nworked together to shape a common vision of\nindustrial forestry in Alaska (i.e., built the horizontal\nlinks among subsystems), which they viewed as\n\nboth the best path to economic growth and self-\nsufficiency and the best practice for using and\nmanaging the region\u2019s abundant forest resources.\n\nGrowth Phase [r] 1947\u20131975\n\nThe passage of the Tongass Timber Act (TTA) in\n1947 was a landmark event in forest governance that\nmoved the Tongass system into the growth [r] phase.\nWith the TTA, Tongass officials applied a federally\nmandated blueprint to mobilize the resources and\nexpertise required to make industrial forestry a\nreality in Alaska\u2014analogous to the rapid biomass\naccumulation and altered competitive balance\namong species in an early successional forest. In the\nTongass, this involved development of a trained\nworkforce and infrastructure; long-term timber\nleases that altered the relationship between forest\nmanagers and forest users; and increased production\nof forest products (Fig. 2). By authorizing long-term\nguaranteed contracts, favorable scaling and pricing\nrules, and several other subsidies, the TTA provided\nthe impetus needed to overcome economic\nthresholds and transform to a new state of industrial\nforestry.\n\nThe provisions of the TTA were framed by\nlegislators, Tongass officials, and timber-industry\nexecutives. The latter two groups of actors had\nnegotiated terms of lease contracts before the\nlegislation\u2019s passage (Rakestraw 1989). Other\ninterests, including other federal agencies with\nstakes in Alaska land management, were summarily\nexcluded from negotiations, and the bill received\nlittle debate in Congress. The preparation and\npassage of the TTA galvanized the close links\namong agency, legislative, and private-industry\nactors (Rakestraw 1989, Nie 2006), forming a\n\u201cpolicy monopoly\u201d (Baumgartner and Jones 1993,\nKingdon 1995, True et al. 1999) of the Tongass\nsystem, which achieved unprecedented measures to\nfoster industrial-scale forestry, including long-term\nleases that guaranteed non-competitive access to\nmillions of acres of publicly owned forest land.\nLease holders were required to operate pulp mills\nin the region and, in return, received low-interest\nloans, a favorable log-scaling system, and refunds\nof road-building costs (Soderberg and DuRette\n1988). Harvest units in leases were planned largely\nby company foresters and then released to lease\nholders on demand (without open bidding) by the\nTongass. The U.S. Forest Service planning process\nat this time was relatively unfettered by legislative\n\nThis content downloaded from \n\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd24.162.145.200 on Mon, 22 Mar 2021 15:33:51 UTC\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \n\nAll use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms\n\nhttp://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art5/\n\n\nEcology and Society 14(2): 5\nhttp://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art5/\n\ncomplications, public participation, or judicial\ndecisions (Nie 2006). As a result, there was a low\ndegree of transparency and a high degree of internal\ncontrol in the execution of the long-term timber\ncontracts; such traits are characteristic of industries\noperating on public resources through a policy\nmonopoly (Repetto 1988).\n\nEarly in this period, the Tongass system mobilized\nrapidly in the direction prescribed and supported by\nits policy monopoly. Immediately after the TTA,\nthe U.S. Forest Service and the newly formed\nKetchikan Pulp Company (KPC) agreed to\npreliminary terms of a lease contract. The KPC\ncontract was finalized in 1951 and guaranteed over\n8.5 billion board feet of timber over 50 years, subject\nto 5-year reviews by the U.S. Forest Service; the\nKPC contract set aside nearly one-fifth of the\nTongass for exclusive bidding rights (Soderberg and\nDuRette 1988). In 1953, the Japanese-owned\nAlaska Pulp Development Co. was incorporated in\nthe United States and signed a 50-year, 4.5 billion\nboard foot contract requiring construction of a large\nsawmill and pulp mill in Sitka. By 1959, the Alaska\nPulp Company (APC) was in operation in Sitka.\nAnother long-term contract with the Pacific\nNorthwest Timber Co. was finalized with the\nconstruction of large sawmill in Wrangell. Other\nlease offerings included large tracts in some of the\nmost biologically rich areas of the Tongass, e.g.,\none lease included nearly 90% of productive forests\non Admiralty Island, which today exists as a\nkeystone reserve of regional biodiversity (Beier\n2008).\n\nWithin 5 years of passage of the TTA, roughly 14\nbillion board feet of Tongass timber was under\ncontract to lease holders. In 1953, Regional Forester\nHeintzleman retired from the U.S. Forest Service\nand was appointed Territorial Governor of Alaska,\nwhere he continued vigorous pursuit of\nprogressively larger timber leases in the region\n(Rakestraw 1989). The three existing lease contracts\nproduced over 90% of Tongass timber harvested\nduring the 1960s and 1970s. In the early 1970s, the\nsystem\u2019s growth phase reached several milestones:\nmaximum annual harvest from the Tongass (560\nMBF), maximum Alaskan share of U.S. timber\nexports to Japan (42%), and the small town of\nKetchikan became the third-largest producer of\ncellulose pulp in the world.\n\nDuring this period, a series of legislative and judicial\ndecisions (Appendix 3), beginning in 1960 with the\n\nMultiple Use Sustained Yield Act (MUSYA), began\nto erode the discretional authority of the U.S. Forest\nService (LeMaster 1984). These \u201cperturbations\u201d to\nthe Tongass policy subsystem were largely driven\nby the growing influence of the U.S. environmental\nmovement. With the exception of one major lawsuit\n(Sierra Club v Hardin), these events were not\nspecific to the Tongass and did not significantly\ninfluence system behavior, based on harvest trends\n(Fig. 2). However, these events did begin to\nchallenge the Tongass policy monopoly and its\ncontrol over forest governance by establishing new\nrules and venues for debate and decision making.\nFor this reason, these events provide a window into\nhow the Tongass system was stabilized, or\nconserved, in the face of change\u2014these interactions\nare the focus of the following section.\n\nIn summary, during the growth [r] phase, Tongass\ntimber outputs grew rapidly and stabilized at a\nharvest level roughly 20 times greater than during\nthe organization [\u03b1] phase (Fig. 2). This\ntransformation in the Tongass system resulted from\na solidification of the links among the institutional,\npolicy, and economic subsystems, creating a rigid\nsystem that had minimal transparency or links to\nother processes such as the environmental lobby or\nsmall-scale logging companies that had interests in\nTongass governance. The mills in Ketchikan, Sitka,\nand Wrangell prospered, and the regional industry\nsupported an estimated 3500 local jobs and\nnumerous local schools, which benefited from\ndirect transfers of timber-based revenues (Allen et\nal. 1998). At the beginning of the [r] phase,\nlegislation created positive feedbacks in the policy\nsubsystem that triggered implementation of the\nTongass system; and toward its conclusion,\nlegislation created negative feedbacks that\nincreased the rigidity of internal links among all\nsubsystems of the Tongass. During this period, the\neconomic subsystem was driven largely by positive\nfeedbacks fostering continued growth in forest-\nproducts manufacturing (Appendix 2), which\npeaked in 1970. Because of the tight links among\nthe three subsystems, the positive feedbacks in the\npolicy and economic subsystems drove the growth\nof the Tongass system.\n\nConservation phase [K] 1975\u20131990\n\nBefore 1975, the Tongass system and its policy\nmonopoly remained largely unfettered by changes\nin public opinion and federal policy associated with\n\nThis content downloaded from \n\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd24.162.145.200 on Mon, 22 Mar 2021 15:33:51 UTC\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \n\nAll use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms\n\nhttp://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art5/\n\n\nEcology and Society 14(2): 5\nhttp://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol14/iss2/art5/\n\nthe environmental movement. In 1975, for the first\ntime, a federal court ruled against the practice of\nclearcut logging in the Tongass. This event moved\nthe Tongass system into a conservation [K] phase\n\u2014a state analogous to the \u201cclimax\u201d stage of a mature\nforest when the dominant canopy trees strongly\ninfluence endogenous conditions and the system is\nlargely resilient to disturbance (Holling and\nGunderson 2002). During this phase, the Tongass\nsystem faced external, converging drivers of change\nin public policy (Nie 2006), institutional\ngovernance (LeMaster 1984), and global markets\n(Crone 2004). The interactions of these drivers with\ncomponents of the Tongass system revealed the\nmechanisms providing stability and resilience, as\nwell as incipient vulnerabilities. "parts": ["### Values and Perspectives on Resource Use\n\n**Garrett Hardin&#x27;s &#x27;Tragedy of the Commons&#x27;** posits that individuals acting independently and rationally according to each one&#x27;s self-interest behave contrary to the whole group&#x27;s long-term best interests by depleting a common resource. This theory is undergirded by the values of individualism and the assumption that resources are limited and must be protected from overuse by individual actors. Hardin&#x27;s approach often suggests regulatory or privatization solutions to manage resources.\n\n**Elinor Ostrom&#x27;s &#x27;Community Governance&#x27;** counters the tragedy by showing how local communities can successfully manage resources without external controls or privatization, through collective action and self-governance. Her theory is grounded in values of community, mutual benefits, and adaptability, demonstrating that collective, context-specific solutions can sustainably manage resources.\n\n### Assumptions in Hardin&#x27;s Theory\n\nHardin assumes that:\n1. **Rational Individuals:** People act independently based on rational self-interest, leading inevitably to resource overuse.\n2. **Limited Resources:** Resources are finite and must be either regulated or privatized to prevent depletion.\n3. **Necessity of External Intervention:** External authorities or privatization are needed to manage resources sustainably.\n\nI would argue that while Hardin&#x27;s view helps understand certain dilemmas like pollution or overfishing, it does not account for the complexities of human behavior and the potential for cooperative governance seen in Ostrom\u2019s work. Ostrom\u2019s approach acknowledges the capabilities of communities to create rules and institutions that manage resources effectively without external enforcement.\n\n### Systems of Controls\n\n**Hardin\u2019s Solutions:** Often involve top-down regulations or privatizing resources to align individual incentives with societal good.\n\n**Ostrom\u2019s Solutions:** Focus on bottom-up, community-based management where rules are adapted to specific local conditions and resource systems, demonstrating flexibility and adaptability.\n\n### Real-World Example: Palm Oil Industry\n\n#### Sustainability Measures and Transparency\nThe palm oil industry, often criticized for deforestation and habitat destruction, has seen initiatives like the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) which certifies sustainable palm oil production. Companies under RSPO must adhere to criteria ensuring environmental, economic, and social sustainability.\n\n#### Ethical Production Ratings\nSome palm oil producers have received certifications indicating better practices, but global standards vary significantly, and enforcement is uneven.\n\n#### Potential Improvements\nCompanies could improve by enhancing transparency in supply chains, committing to zero deforestation, and increasing support for smallholder farmers.\n\n#### Argument for Additional Sustainability Measures\nImplementing stricter sustainability measures could significantly benefit the environment by reducing deforestation and carbon emissions. Social benefits include improved conditions for workers and reduced conflict over land. These benefits likely outweigh the costs of implementing such measures, which include increased financial investments and potential short-term decreases in profit margins.\n\n#### Enforcement\nEnforcement could be managed through stricter national regulations, international agreements, and consumer pressure demanding certified products.\n\n#### Complexity and Cost\nTransitioning to sustainable practices involves complex changes in supply chain management, increased costs for certification, and potentially higher operational costs. However, the long-term benefits of maintaining biodiversity, reducing carbon footprints, and improving social outcomes provide a compelling case for these changes.\n\nThis analysis shows the contrast between Hardin&#x27;s approach, which might argue for stringent controls or privatization, and Ostrom&#x27;s, which would advocate for community-led initiatives and local governance structures tailored to the specific context of the palm oil industry."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

These regulations ensure a high standard of ethical production. Costs might also be mitigated by government subsidies and EU funding aimed at promoting sustainable agriculture.\n\n#### System Change Challenges\nTransitioning to more sustainable production involves overcoming challenges like the small scale of many olive farms, which can make it difficult to invest in new technologies. However, cooperative models and shared resources among small producers can facilitate this transition.\n\n### Conclusion\nThe Italian olive oil industry&#x27;s move towards increased sustainability and ethical production is not only feasible but beneficial both environmentally and socially. "]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "87dd2a515f580e56-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "67ccc8e5-fa49-4384-adc6-0611b286cd99", "children": ["e10f5f87-c1a0-42f5-8870-85f7c8a605cb"]}, "e10f5f87-c1a0-42f5-8870-85f7c8a605cb": {"id": "e10f5f87-c1a0-42f5-8870-85f7c8a605cb", "message": {"id": "e10f5f87-c1a0-42f5-8870-85f7c8a605cb", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1714706976.605736, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["The theory of collective action, central to economics, particularly in public economics and political science, refers to the ways in which groups of individuals come together to achieve goals that they may not be able to achieve individually. This theory explores how to provide public goods and manage common resources effectively, often challenging situations where individual rationality does not lead to rational outcomes for the group.\n\n### Key Aspects of the Theory of Collective Action\n\n1. **Public Goods**: These are goods that are non-excludable and non-rivalrous, meaning no one can be excluded from using the good, and one person&#x27;s use does not reduce availability to others. Classic examples include public parks, clean air, and national defense. The theory of collective action seeks to address how such goods can be efficiently provided since they often lead to free-riding behavior where individuals benefit from resources without contributing to their provision.\n\n2. **Free-Rider Problem**: This is a central issue in the theory of collective action. Since everyone can use a public good whether they pay for it or not, individuals may decide not to contribute financially or effort-wise, hoping that others will cover the cost. This behavior can lead to under-provision or non-provision of the necessary goods.\n\n3. **Social Dilemmas**: The theory often deals with social dilemmas like the &quot;tragedy of the commons,&quot; where individual users acting independently according to their own self-interest behave contrary to the common good of all users by depleting or spoiling the shared resource. Garrett Hardin&#x27;s essay on this topic illustrates how shared resources can be overused and destroyed.\n\n4. **Solutions and Institutional Responses**: Mancur Olson, in his book &quot;The Logic of Collective Action,&quot; argues that larger groups need some form of extra incentive to get their members to act in their common interest. Solutions may include coercive government intervention, regulations, privatization, or the creation of institutions that align individual incentives with group goals. Elinor Ostrom&#x27;s work extends this by showing that communities can often self-organize to manage resources sustainably without external authorities if appropriate group norms and rules are established.\n\n### Economic Implications\n\nThe theory has profound implications for economic policies, particularly in how governments and organizations design mechanisms to fund public goods and manage common resources. It impacts tax policies, regulatory approaches, and the provision of subsidies. It also influences international economics in areas like climate change agreements and collective security arrangements.\n\n### Political Science Relevance\n\nIn political science, the theory of collective action informs understanding of how political coalitions form, how lobbying works, and how collective political movements can influence policy changes. It helps explain why some groups are more powerful and effective than others in getting their interests represented in public policy.\n\nThe theory of collective action is crucial in understanding many economic and political behaviors and forms the basis for designing policies that can overcome collective action problems to achieve better outcomes for society as a whole."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true
, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "citations": [], "gizmo_id": "g-V2KIUZSj0", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "aaa2db6e-174e-4b9f-86ed-94429353990a", "request_id": "87dd2a515f580e56-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa2db6e-174e-4b9f-86ed-94429353990a", "children": ["aaa2081c-7c77-4e06-abe7-ddfb9738dcbe"]}, "aaa2081c-7c77-4e06-abe7-ddfb9738dcbe": {"id": "aaa2081c-7c77-4e06-abe7-ddfb9738dcbe", "message": {"id": "aaa2081c-7c77-4e06-abe7-ddfb9738dcbe", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1714707541.860516, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["give outline, summarize and provide an overview of the key ideas presented"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"attachments": [{"id": "file-kl8goQrC96zkHBIkko9pui2a", "size": 597250, "name": "gospel_of_wealth_2017.pdf", "mime_type": "application/pdf"}], "request_id": "87dd38b4accc4bde-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "e10f5f87-c1a0-42f5-8870-85f7c8a605cb", "children": ["c1ab741b-88de-4cb6-9c5f-36ce6261ab34"]}, "c1ab741b-88de-4cb6-9c5f-36ce6261ab34": {"id": "c1ab741b-88de-4cb6-9c5f-36ce6261ab34", "message": {"id": "c1ab741b-88de-4cb6-9c5f-36ce6261ab34", "author": {"role": "tool", "name": "myfiles_browser", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1714707566.926052, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "tether_quote", "url": "file-kl8goQrC96zkHBIkko9pui2a", "domain": "gospel_of_wealth_2017.pdf", "text": "\nThe Scottish-born industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie \n(1835\u20131919) was one of the titans of America\u2019s Gilded Age. He  \nwas also a prolific author, writing hundreds of speeches, articles, \npamphlets, and letters to the editor, as well as seven books, including \nan Autobiography (published posthumously in 1920). Proud of his pen, \nCarnegie is today perhaps most celebrated as the author of a pair  \nof articles first published in 1889, which together have come to be \nknown as The Gospel of Wealth. Here, Carnegie boldly articulated \nhis view of the rich as mere trustees of their wealth who should live \nunostentatiously, provide moderately for their families, and use their \nfortunes to promote the \u201cgeneral good.\u201d He goes on to suggest some \n\u201cbest uses\u201d to which the millionaire can devote his wealth (universities, \nlibraries, medical institutions, public parks, and more). The Gospel of \nWealth caused quite a stir on both sides of the Atlantic, not least for its \nnow famous declaration that \u201cThe man who dies thus rich dies disgraced.\u201d\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Gospel\nof Wealth\n \n\n\n\nTwo articles originally published\nin The North American Review\nJune 1889 &amp; December 1889\n\n\n\nNEW YORK\nCARNEGIE CORPORATION OF NEW YORK\n2017 \n\nThe Gospel\nof Wealth\n Andrew Carnegie\n\n\n\n\n\n1THE GOSPEL OF WEALTH\n\n     he problem of our age is the \nproper administration of wealth, so that the ties of brother-\nhood may still bind together the rich and poor in harmonious \nrelationship. The conditions of human life have not only been \nchanged, but revolutionized, within the past few hundred years. \nIn former days there was little difference between the dwell-\ning, dress, food, and environment of the chief and those of his \nretainers. The Indians are today where civilized man then was. \nWhen visiting the Sioux, I was led to the wigwam of the chief. It \nwas just like the others in external appearance, and even within \nthe difference was trifling between it and those of the poorest \nof his braves. The contrast between the palace of the million-\naire and the cottage of the laborer with us today measures the \nchange which has come with civilization. \n\nThis change, however, is not to be deplored, but welcomed as \nhighly beneficial. It is well, nay, essential for the progress of the \nrace, that the houses of some should be homes for all that is \nhighest and best in literature and the arts, and for all the refine-\nments of civilization, rather than that none should be so. Much \nbetter this great irregularity than universal squalor. Without \nwealth there can be no Maecenas. The \u201cgood old times\u201d were not \ngood old times. Neither master nor servant was as well situated \nthen as today. A relapse to old conditions would be disastrous \nto both\u2014not the least so to him who serves\u2014and would sweep \n\n I. \nWEALTH\n\n\n\n2\n\naway civilization with it. But whether the change be for good or \nill, it is upon us, beyond our power to alter, and therefore to be \naccepted and made the best of. It is a waste of time to criticize \nthe inevitable.\n\nIt is easy to see how the change has come. One illustration will \nserve for almost every phase of the cause. In the manufacture of \nproducts we have the whole story. It applies to all combinations \nof human industry, as stimulated and enlarged by the inventions \nof this scientific age. Formerly articles were manufactured at \nthe domestic hearth or in small shops which formed part of the \nhousehold. The master and his apprentices worked side by side, \nthe latter living with the master, and therefore subject to the \nsame conditions. When these apprentices rose to be masters, \nthere was little or no change in their mode of life, and they, in \nturn, educated in the same routine succeeding apprentices. \nThere was, substantially, social equality, and even political \nequality, for those engaged in industrial pursuits had then little \nor no political voice in the State.\n\nBut the inevitable result of such a mode of manufacture was \ncrude articles at high prices. Today the world obtains commod-\nities of excellent quality at prices which even the generation \npreceding this would have deemed incredible. In the commer-\ncial world similar causes have produced similar results, and the \nrace is benefited thereby. The poor enjoy what the rich could not \nbefore afford. What were the luxuries have become the necessar-\nies of life. The laborer has now more comforts than the farmer \nhad a few generations ago. The farmer has more luxuries than \nthe landlord had, and is more richly clad and better housed. The \nlandlord has books and pictures rarer, and appointments more \nartistic, than the King could then obtain.\n\nThe price we pay for this salutary change is, no doubt, great. We \nassemble thousands of operatives in the factory, in the mine, \n\n\n\n3THE GOSPEL OF WEALTH\n\nand in the countinghouse, of whom the employer can know \nlittle or nothing, and to whom the employer is little better than \na myth. All intercourse between them is at an end. Rigid Castes \nare formed, and, as usual, mutual ignorance breeds mutual \ndistrust. Each Caste is without sympathy for the other, and \nready to credit anything disparaging in regard to it. Under the \nlaw of competition, the employer of thousands is forced into the \nstrictest economies, among which the rates paid to labor figure \nprominently, and often there is friction between the employer \nand the employed, between capital and labor, between rich and \npoor. Human society loses homogeneity.\n\nThe price which society pays for the law of competition, like the \nprice it pays for cheap comforts and luxuries, is also great; but \nthe advantages of this law are also greater still, for it is to this \nlaw that we owe our wonderful material development, which \nbrings improved conditions in its train. But, whether the law \nbe benign or not, we must say of it, as we say of the change in \nthe conditions of men to which we have referred: It is here; we \ncannot evade it; no substitutes for it have been found; and while \nthe law may be sometimes hard for the individual, it is best for \nthe race, because it insures the survival of the fittest in every \ndepartment. We accept and welcome, therefore, as conditions \nto which we must accommodate ourselves, great inequality \nof environment, the concentration of business, industrial and \ncommercial, in the hands of a few, and the law of competition \nbetween these, as being not only beneficial, but essential for the \nfuture progress of the race. Having accepted these, it follows \nthat there must be great scope for the exercise of special ability \nin the merchant and in the manufacturer who has to conduct \naffairs upon a great scale. That this talent for organization \nand management is rare among men is proved by the fact that \nit invariably secures for its possessor enormous rewards, no \nmatter where or under what laws or conditions. The experienced \nin affairs always rate the man whose services can be obtained \n\n\n\n4\n\nas a partner as not only the first consideration, but such as to \nrender the question of his capital scarcely worth considering, for \nsuch men soon create capital; while, without the special talent \nrequired, capital soon takes wings. Such men become interested \nin firms or corporations using millions; and estimating only \nsimple interest to be made upon the capital invested, it is inevi-\ntable that their income must exceed their expenditures, and that \nthey must accumulate wealth. Nor is there any middle ground \nwhich such men can occupy, because the great manufacturing or \ncommercial concern which does not earn at least interest upon \nits capital soon becomes bankrupt. It must either go forward or \nfall behind: to stand still is impossible. It is a condition essential \nfor its successful operation that it should be thus far profitable, \nand even that, in addition to interest on capital, it should make \nprofit. It is a law, as certain as any of the others named, that \nmen possessed of this peculiar talent for affairs, under the free \nplay of economic forces, must, of necessity, soon be in receipt \nof more revenue than can be judiciously expended upon them-\nselves; and this law is as beneficial for the race as the others.\n\nObjections to the foundations upon which society is based are \nnot in order, because the condition of the race is better with \nthese than it has been with any others which have been tried. \nOf the effect of any new substitutes proposed we cannot be \nsure. The Socialist or Anarchist who seeks to overturn pres-\nent conditions is to be regarded as attacking the foundation \nupon which civilization itself rests, for civilization took its start \nfrom the day that the capable, industrious workman said to his \nincompetent and lazy fellow, \u201cIf thou dost not sow, thou shalt \nnot reap,\u201d and thus ended primitive Communism by separat-\ning the drones from the bees. One who studies this subject will \nsoon be brought face to face with the conclusion that upon the \nsacredness of property civilization itself depends\u2014the right \nof the laborer to his hundred dollars in the savings bank, and \nequally the legal right of the millionaire to his millions. To \n\n\n\n5THE GOSPEL OF WEALTH\n\nthose who propose to substitute Communism for this intense \nIndividualism the answer, therefore, is: The race has tried that. \nAll progress from that barbarous day to the present time has \nresulted from its displacement. Not evil, but good, has come to \nthe race from the accumulation of wealth by those who have the \nability and energy that produce it. But even if we admit for a \nmoment that it might be better for the race to discard its present \nfoundation, Individualism\u2014that it is a nobler ideal that man \n\nshould labor, not for himself alone, but in and for a brotherhood \nof his fellows, and share with them all in common, realizing \nSwedenborg\u2019s idea of Heaven, where, as he says, the angels \nderive their happiness, not from laboring for self, but for each \nother\u2014even admit all this, and a sufficient answer is, This is not \nevolution, but revolution. It necessitates the changing of human \nnature itself\u2014a work of eons, even if it were good to change it, \nwhich we cannot know. It is not practicable in our day or in our \nage. Even if desirable theoretically, it belongs to another and \nlong-succeeding sociological stratum. Our duty is with what \nis practicable now; with the next step possible in our day and \ngeneration. It is criminal to waste our energies in endeavoring to \nuproot, when all we can profitably or possibly accomplish is to \nbend the universal tree of humanity a little in the direction most \nfavorable to the production of good fruit under existing circum-\nstances. We might as well urge the destruction of the highest \n\nOur duty is with what is  \npracticable now; with  \nthe next step possible in  \nour day and generation.\n\n\n\n6\n\nexisting type of man because he failed to reach our ideal as to \nfavor the destruction of Individualism, Private Property, the \nLaw of Accumulation of Wealth, and the Law of Competition; \nfor these are the highest results of human experience, the soil \nin which society so far has produced the best fruit. Unequally or \nunjustly, perhaps, as these laws sometimes operate, and imper-\nfect as they appear to the Idealist, they are, nevertheless, like \nthe highest type of man, the best and most valuable of all that \nhumanity has yet accomplished.\n\nWe start, then, with a condition of affairs under which the best \ninterests of the race are promoted, but which inevitably gives \nwealth to the few. Thus far, accepting conditions as they exist, \nthe situation can be surveyed and pronounced good. The ques-\ntion then arises\u2014and, if the foregoing be correct, it is the only \nquestion with which we have to deal\u2014What is the proper mode \nof administering wealth after the laws upon which civilization \nis founded have thrown it into the hands of the few? And it is of \nthis great question that I believe I offer the true solution. It will \nbe understood that fortunes are here spoken of, not moderate \nsums saved by many years of effort, the returns from which \nare required for the comfortable maintenance and education \nof families. This is not wealth, but only competence, which it \nshould be the aim of all to acquire.\n\nThere are but three modes in which surplus wealth can be \ndisposed of. It can be left to the families of the decedents; or \nit can be bequeathed for public purposes; or, finally, it can be \nadministered during their lives by its possessors. Under the \nfirst and second modes most of the wealth of the world that \nhas reached the few has hitherto been applied. Let us in turn \nconsider each of these modes. The first is the most injudicious. \nIn monarchical countries, the estates and the greatest portion of \nthe wealth are left to the first son, that the vanity of the parent \nmay be gratified by the thought that his name and title are to \n\n\n\n7THE GOSPEL OF WEALTH\n\ndescend to succeeding generations unimpaired. The condition \nof this class in Europe today teaches the futility of such hopes or \nambitions. The successors have become impoverished through \ntheir follies or from the fall in the value of land. Even in Great \nBritain the strict law of entail has been found inadequate to \nmaintain the status of a hereditary class. Its soil is rapidly pass-\ning into the hands of the stranger. Under republican institutions \nthe division of property among the children is much fairer, \nbut the question which forces itself upon thoughtful men in all \nlands is: Why should men leave great fortunes to their children? \nIf this is done from affection, is it not misguided affection? \nObservation teaches that, generally speaking, it is not well \nfor the children that they should be so burdened. Neither is it \nwell for the state. Beyond providing for the wife and daughters \nmoderate sources of income, and very moderate allowances \nindeed, if any, for the sons, men may well hesitate, for it is no \nlonger questionable that great sums bequeathed oftener work \nmore for the injury than for the good of the recipients. Wise men \nwill soon conclude that, for the best interests of the members of \ntheir families and of the state, such bequests are an improper \nuse of their means.\n\nIt is not suggested that men who have failed to educate their sons \nto earn a livelihood shall cast them adrift in poverty.
